description: You should grab a cup of coffee and sit in front of the cafe, looking the world goes by. It's amazing.
author: Dang Lam N.

description: Someone got me two pastries as a gift. The puff pastry one was pretty good but the nut cake topped with raspberry was disappointing. The color of the cake reminded me of mold or vomit. I never met a cake I couldn't love until this one. I'm not sure what they are called, but am uploading pictures to help you identify them.
author: Julia C.

description:
Corporate feels employees are replace-able, so naturally, no one gives a hoot. And they shouldn't. Work your ass off only to get laid off the second sales dip.

Employees must sacrifice their 10 min break if they need to use the bathroom. Is it hot out? Corporate will tell you to drink water to keep you safe--- but you aren't able to pee. It's hell.  Bladder infections anyone?

Yah you wonder why staff sucks? LMAO. No one can afford to live in SF on that pay. Poverty creators!
author: Aune M.

description: Visiting again the staff is very rude , coffe was cold, almond brioche shitty just like their attitude
author: Kevin N.

description: Tried to sell me an old croissant. Happily exchanged it for a fresh one when I asked.  I'm often taken for a tourist due to accent. They can't know that I know that Rulli should stand for quality not tourist trap. They train a new summer crew - that's fine but quality has to be right. Team lead may be British ("take away" - instead of "take out") so he should know quality.
author: Flo B.

description:
Got a coffee and breakfast here while I was waiting for my place to be seen in the Apple Store across the road. 
The plus of this spot is it's got great terrace seating overlooking union square. Great sunshine on a good day as it's south facing. 

Nice to sit outside and they also serve beers and wine so it's even good in the evening. 

The downside is the service is very poor. Found the staff to be rude when ordering, with no please or thank you's. 
It's also a very touristy spot so the food quality is poor and it's over priced. Also no easy access to restrooms. 
If they cleaned up these pitfalls this could be a really popular spot.
author: Derek M.

description: Im going to start by saying the latte I had here was the best I've had! Foam was super dense and coffee flavor was just perfect! Absolutely delicious, pastries are scrumptious, the only thing I would change to make this a 5 start (in my humble opinion) would be to work on the customer service or lack of, walked i. With not a person (customer) in sight, 4 to 5 employees behind the counter, I said hello and didn't get a response....waited and not one employee acknowledged me and my mum even though they looked at me straight in the eye, finally a gurl took our order (without greeting or remotely showing any emotion or desire to fake smile) asked a few questions and was given shirt answers...not happy with customer service at all! Coming from an extensive customer service background I would have loved to have been "wanted " in their establishment . Still coffee was Delicious. Note to owner and management work on your employees customer service.
author: Tulio T.

description: I used to love this place!  Tasty cappuccino on a nice day.  Their restaurant on Chestnut was beautiful with great food.  I'm here Union Square today and a different story. Maybe new owners?  There are notices of hiring and such.  I walk in and the overhead menu is gone and I ask and woman says we are out and I said but it was posted. She was short with me.  I ordered small cappuccino and a small pellegrino.  (Mid size bottle really) but not much and $9.10. Wow. They repeated cost and smiled when I asked why so much.  Prices should be posted. And the cappuccino is not very good
author: Linda M.

description: Location is great for people watching. That's about all that's positive here. The coffee was meh, and I wouldn't dream of touching the food.
author: Eric B.

description: Very rude coffee maker/server (guy). We know that everywhere is understaffed but there's no reason to ruin someone's day with an attitude!
author: Fadwa A.

description: Awful service.   No straws for drinks, no half and half and this is a coffee joint and they're passing these cups to guest for water.   Whack whack whack!!   Owner should shut this place down and let someone come in that knows how to handle business.
author: Rhobin D.

description: Great food; pastries, sandwiches, salads, juices, gelato and people watching!  The crazy homeless are a nuisance and either grab your food or hassle you for money, but I think they have a private security guy that chases them out depending on how they are acting.  I had a great cheese ravioli with tomato sauce and fresh basil.  A glass of Chianti, and then I followed it up with a lovely cappuccino.  Some old guy confined to a rolling wheel chair kept going by playing latin music, so it was a fun sunny day at the square.  Oops, I forgot to mention the brownie, and from what I understand, everything is made fresh daily in Marin and delivered.  Very Cool.  I saw some negative reviews, but my experiences have always been very good.  I do wish they could speed up the line when it is busy, my opinion.   Off to buy some shoes.
author: Francesca S.

description:
My friend just got the spring caprese salad with bean salad. She said it had very little dressing on it, or flavor, and that it needs salt. 

She went in to ask for salt and they told her they had no salt available in the cafe at all! No salt shakers, no salt packets, not even a container of salt behind the counter. 

Be aware, the salad is bland and no salt is available.
author: katie s.

description:
I'm about to say something that's not very nice.
But I have to be honest.
Every time I come here, I really, really miss the old chestnut street location.  (It's now Ristobar)

This place would be 10 times better if it weren't for...

1: the tourists
2: the staff

There.
The unpleasantries are out of the way.

I think the biggest negative w this location is the sheer volume that they get.  It's too hard to keep everything neat & clean.  Meaning you'll often find something reminiscent of a bus terminal if you come by after a rush.  I've never seen the outside tables NOT in disarray.  

The fact that the cashier didn't know what something in the pastry case even was when I asked him about it can't help matters.  He had to ask another employee, holding up the line.  Not good.  

It's Union Square Park.  You've got knockout views.  You've got knockout pastries & desserts.  You're at a world class destination.  When it's a gorgeous day, it is fabulous to be here.  

So if you can manage to get a clean table, you're really in the money.

I've been a fan of Rulli's talent for a long time.  Since back when he only had the Larkspur bakery.  He is a true artisan.  

Try to visit his original location in Larkspur.  There you'll find zero distractions from his fantastic creations.

3 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
I can't understand why Americans keep trying to create Italian Style coffee shops (bar, as they are known as in Italy) with the same vibe and service that Starbucks offers.

1- Coffee is disgusting. If you'd serve this dirty water in Italy, you'd close your business in 1 month

2- Coffee is served in paper cups, even when you drink it at the table. 

3- The pastries are as bad as the ones you find in Starbucks

4- Service is slow, inefficient and knows nothing about how to run an Italian style coffee shop.

5- Wayyyyy to expensive for the lame products you are offering

Here's a suggestion for the owners. Change the name of your establishment to 'Bob's Coffee on Union Square'. By doing so, you don't build up expectations for the countless people that walk in, hoping to get a taste of Italian service and quality.
author: Ricky R.

description: I used to like to come to this cafe to enjoy a great coffee or champagne and a delicious hot sandwich (lots of vegetarian options) outside on their patio. The nice patio is still here but the food and coffee are terrible now. There are no yummy hot plated foods or nice lattes. Just cold egg sandwiches in plastic wrap and bad coffee in a cheap foam cup. I can't stress how disappointed I was to take a loved one here this afternoon. Such bad coffee. Such bad food.
author: Pamela C.

description: I have been here many times and mostly enjoyed people watching. It's never been so bad as this time. We were 3 of us. One of my friends ordered a tea and 2 of us ordered flat whites. We got a table outside. The tea was given to us promptly. After 5 mins we went back to check on our coffee orders. There were 3 cups on the counter. I asked the guy who had taken our order, which two were ours. He shrugged his shoulder and said I don't know. We stood there for a while and then best guessed our order and took it. Today while going through my receipts I realized he charged us for 3 coffees and 1 tea. Such a rude person and corrupt setup.
author: Shabina M.

description:
On of my coworkers loves coming to Rulli. On Friday, October 9th around 10:30am, she came back with breakfast pastries for the office.

I ended up trying the custard filled pastry. Flaky and not to sweet. Perfect for me. I typically don't crave sweets in the morning, but I was hungry and this hit the spot.

I've never been to the cafe itself, but it looks like a nice place to chill, have a cup of coffee and people watch. I may do that the next time I'm in Union Square. I hear their coffee is really good!
author: Elena N.

description:
Rulli tends to be a little chaotic, and while that's to be expected in Union Square, the staff tend to seem a little more frazzled than they should be. With that said, they are nice; when my friend and I each ordered ham and brie panini, we then were given ham, egg, and cheese croissant sandwiches. When we pointed out that the orders were wrong, we were allowed to keep the wrong sandwiches and got our actual orders. (The croissant sandwiches were even better than the panini, as it turned out!)

Nice café food, nothing too special but definitely good enough eats. I do see why people are complaining about the prices; when there are so many other options as close as Macy's food court, it doesn't seem like Rulli quite measures up.
author: AJ P.

description:
I am shocked by the low reviews at this spot - until I read through them. Some of these reviews are from tourists who are annoyed by pricing, so take my word for it when I say that this spot is awesome. 

My husband and I came here for a quick brunch this past weekend - and though I'm a Bay Area native, I've never had the pleasure of visiting this cafe until Saturday. We got in a quick-moving line and both chose are meals. I got the favorito - the eggplant, mozzarella, bell pepper, and tomato panini and he had an Italian meat panini, I can't remember what it was specifically. In either case, we both loved our food items. 

While in line, you see the huge array of different snacks and we debated getting a chocolate croissant and cinnamon twists originally, but the opted to get the delicious looking sandwiches instead. The baked goods are also huge portions so we thought we might get too full. 

He got an espresso and I opted for the chai latte - which is probably one of the BEST chai lattes I've ever had. We got a table on the patio, in the center and had a beautiful view of people dancing to tango, and people watched. Service was awesome - the cashier was courteous and helpful, and our plates were immediately cleaned off by a waiter who was bussing the area. 

Such a quaint and nice experience - definitely a fun stop if you're in town!
author: Raji R.

description: Yuck. Blasting rap music and it was loud, dirty tables not wiped down, a girl behind counter had her finger in her mouth, girl behind register was rude and told me they ran out of chai. I walked out.
author: Stefanie A.

description:
It's really unfortunate. They've got the prime location in Union Square so they've obviously decided to get by on that alone and not offer anything else of value... like a decent cup of coffee (ever tasted coffee that's been sitting on a burner for too long), or fresh pastries, or efficient service (the girl working there this last time was nice and moving at what I'd call a steady, measured pace, but she was literally all alone...working the register, making the coffees, serving the pastries...with a steady line of customers... Poor thing). 

Last time I got suckered in (after a few laps around the ice rink last winter) I said 'never again'. But today I just couldn't resist the late-summer view. Now I'm back to 'never again'.
author: Anton M.

description:
Quality coffee and espresso, good pastries, served fast and friendly, with great people watching (you sit right on Union Square). Warning: DO NOT GO HERE FOR A FULL MEAL. This place is a cafe designed for a break from the Union Square-area chaos (indoor and outdoor seating) with a tasty snack and/or beverage or something to-go.

I love the Emporio Rulli in Larkspur, by my hometown, and was pleased to see it here.Thank you San Francisco for choosing two quality cafes for Union Square (check out Bancarella as well).

Quality items I've had:
 - Espresso-drinks
 - Coffee
 - Croissants

They also have a variety of small sandwiches, cheeses, chocolates, and wine amongst other things.

I took my father and my kids to Union Square for a holiday shopping extravaganza and sat outside with a coffee and a croissant for a much-needed break. The people watching was nice. You never feel like a tourist when you're sedentary and watching other people. THOSE people are the tourists, right?!
author: David S.

description: The rudest cashier for take out I've experienced in some time. Such a great spot ruined but bad customer service. Coffee was good, but ruined
author: Glenn B.

description:
I was so excited to visit this cafe, conveniently located on the corner of Union Square with beautiful natural lighting and a classy (but relaxed) atmosphere... But my experience here was so utterly disappointing. I got to the cafe around 3pm on Sunday (yesterday), so hopefully some owner/manager can figure out who was working at this time and let them know that their behavior was unacceptable. 

My main complaint: the workers here are terribly unfriendly. The guy at the register took my order and punched it in without a single smile, and seemed impatient when I took an extra 5 seconds to figure out which cookie I wanted. One of the other workers behind the counter wasn't at the register, but was grabbing the pastries for customers. She asked me which cookie I wanted, so I asked her for the one with pistachios in it. She didn't get the one I wanted (I guess there were two types with pistachios) so I apologized profusely and asked her to get the other one. She responded irritatedly with "That cookie doesn't have pistachios in it." I apologized again and asked her to get the other one anyway, and she begrudgingly got it for me -- NO SMILE the entire time. When I sat down to eat the cookie, guess what? There were pistachios in it. 

The food itself wasn't bad at all. I got a cookie with chocolate chips and nuts (sweet but not overly so), a cafe latte, and a scoop of stracciatella gelato (expensive pricing for tiny portions, but expected for such a touristy area). 

It was a busy day, so maybe the workers were just feeling grumpy or overworked. But I really hope some action will be taken in training the workers better in terms of customer service, or hiring some friendlier people. Until then, I'll be getting my coffee fix elsewhere.
author: Christine L.

description: DO NOT EAT HERE IF YOU HAVE FOOD ALLERGIES. Their staff is incredibly unknowable about all allergies and know nothing about the food they serve. If they do not know the ingredients they will make a guess that may cost your health. During my last visit, after realizing I had consumed gluten, I went to let them know their mistake and was appalled at their lack of care towards the situation and their customers. If I could give zero stars I would.
author: Martha E.

description:
I know I ordered the wrong thing...

I wanted something like a hot mocca/hot chocolate when we saw the Cioccolato del Doge which sounded so good http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/emporio-rulli-union-square-san-francisco?select=KkiM0uC7vO348IkObO42fw#eKMEfRC4yVc8dwFVkMCYSA.  I was never so wrong.  It was thick like syrup, cloyingly rich and sweet, and a rip-off when two of them cost nearly $10 for a dinky cup where a good 2/3s of it was the whipped cream...
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/emporio-rulli-union-square-san-francisco?select=KkiM0uC7vO348IkObO42fw#EeY879iyWQO3vP_etk5jKg

Totally unsatisfying as a drink, I was left parched after I had it...
author: Lawrence L.

description:
$9 for a latte and a cup of tea. not even loose leaf, but bagged tea. HAH!

GTFOOH
author: Susy C.

description:
$3.00 for a stale croissant from Costco WTF?
All this does is make me never come back!
You don't save money doing this it far more expensive than you think!
author: Grant H.

description: After visiting this place with my friend today I was very disappointed by the horrible customer service. After ordering two Italian sodas, I saw the girl making it and notice that the sparkling water was old and had no bubbles in it. So I ask the girl to remake my drinks, where she was surprised, so I had to explain her that the Italian soda has to be made with flavored syrup over ice and fill with sparkling water. At the end the drinks taste as plain water with some color and no flavor what so ever. It's really painful for me to see this place going down. The service is horrible and the place is dirty and fill with flys. I wouldn't recommend this place to my friends which is really sad. I used to love this place and it was completely different.
author: Yana Y.

description:
Yelps 365 Review Challenge 2014 - Los Angeles #63 - #365

Nice little upscale coffee shop in the middle of Union Square, where you can enjoy a sip of coffee and people watch in the same time. 

The ambiance felt as though you were eating in a coffee shop outside of a museum. Decorative plants and trees flow outside of the seating area with the downtown buildings towering above you. This truly is a downtown experience, other than your typical corner coffee shop (Starbucks).
author: Paul B.

description:
Well, I know where to go when I want over priced coffee and medicore cakes, served by unfriendly and impatient staff.

I was on vacay and I was looking for a coffee and maybe a little snack.  I went here, I was not impressed.  It was nice to be able to go sit in the park and people-watch. 

Maybe they were just really busy the day I was there or something, but I certainly would not recommend this, or at least not for a tourist.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I've been here several times over the years. Both this location as well as the Emporio Rulli at San Francisco airport. 

Overall it was not a pleasant experience. Let me explain why. While it's in the best of central SF locations, the daily maintenance and customer service are sub-standard. We came to the cafe late yesterday afternoon. There were not too many patrons to clutter my perspective. 

Upon arrival I noticed that many of the tables had not been cleared and the garbage was overflowing. Not to worry, we took a space in the corner and found it to be dilapidated picnic table, sticky with the previous patrons' food items. While patiently waiting for our food I had the perfect vantage point to observe one of the staff members who was attending to all the garbage duties. After finishing those tasks he promptly resumed taking food to the patrons' tables without washing his hands!!! Yuck! We watched the staff curse one another in a jocular manner, completely inattentive to the patrons who were entering and leaving the cafe. No wonder I had to ask twice to get my cake. 

After paying $18 (including tip) for two espressos and a cheesecake, one might expect a pleasant experience. No, it wasn't spoiled by an inebriated homeless dude or a noisy tourist bus. Emporia Rulli managed to bungle it all on their own. 

How can they afford this location which such crappy service?!!?? Oh yeah, it's from the endless supply of tourists who want a draft beer in Union Square.
author: Nathan W.

description:
Every time I go here they steal my money. I remember paying 20 dollars for a 7 dollar salmon sandwich and then losing another 20 somehow when I came back years later. By now it's been so long not much can be done about it! But I'm sure you notice when your cash is overflowing at the end of the day. Are they not already pricey enough?

I would rate lower but the strawberry shortcake was above average.

5 STARS for the tiramisus.
But inconsistent. It appears they don't always have it. One day they have two, next day... maybe? No trace. Get the slice, it's cheaper than the small plastic packaged one.
THUMBS UP for the fedora cake.
It's a real cake, bigger than the one across the square at Bancarella. Tastes better too. Again, inconsistent in that they don't always have it. Fear it might just go out of sales and Emporio Rulli would lose the only good things about it in the square.
author: M R.

description: Great Caesar but we walked 2 miles for it and they were out with w no apologies. Stale croissants.
author: Patti P.

description:
There is nothing special about this place whatsoever. Well maybe except for the fact that it is directly located in Union Square. I would be better off walking to a nearby Starbucks for coffee. The place is unclassy and the service is basic. With multiple orders placed, the baristas did not bother helping to figure out who ordered what.

The only redeeming quality is the outdoor seating so everyone can enjoy their basic food & beverages while appreciating the rest of Union Square.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Came here for the first time with a buddy.  The place was nearly empty. He ordered a cinnamon twist and I ordered a cinnamon swirl.  The girl have us both the twist.  I said I got the swirl.  She grabbed the plate and toss the twist into the display case and grab the swirl.  We also ordered tea and she made that and put it on the pickup counter and walk away. Didn't say that was our drinks or anything.   She didn't even give me my reciept. 

Enough about her.  

The food was okay and tea was nothing special for the price. There are plenty of other spots in the area.
author: T L.

description: Stopped here after a Alfred Hitchcock Walking Tour on 8/28/16 while on vacation in SF.  This was our first time at this cafe/bakery.  The entire staff were very nice and helpful.  My husband and I shared a Carmelized Brioche and a Sfogliatina (clamshell), of which the latter was our favorite.  I appreciated the choice of coffee which was perfect (I don't like super strong coffee). Lovely indoor seating as well as patio seating.
author: Janet B.

description:
If you're already at Union Square this spot is quick and convenient. Lots of snack choices to tide you over until your next meal. The outdoor seating for people watching is a plus.

Actually, there are a couple of cafes and even a coffee kiosk at Union Square, and this spot is at the corner nearest to Niketown.
author: Peter L.

description:
Update: The manager of this location contacted me and apologized for the experience and I 100% appreciate that. I will give them another go next time I'm in the city. I added another star for him reaching out and will update once I try this spot again.


I am leaving a review strictly on my customer service experience, I will leave an updated review if I have a better experience in future. I came here with my very sweet mother-in-law who wanted a cold coffee drink in the warm afternoon. She preferred a white mocha over ice, which was not on the menu, so tentatively asked if it was an off-menu possibility. Now, I have been to many coffee shops, ranging from the snooty to the down-to earth and have never been looked at like this lady did when she smirked at her and said, 'no, we can't; this isn't Starbucks'.......Wow, I was shocked at the gall of this smarmy little brat. So this wasn't Starbucks? I could've sworn I saw that green mermaid lady on the front door. (dramatic eye roll) Instead of intervening and saying all the wonderfully sarcastic things that came to mind about 10 minutes after we left, I stood by speechless and my MIL ordered a mocha over ice instead.
The moral of the story is this: If a coffee shop doesn't make something I'm looking for, they should (and have, until this place) suggest something they have that is similar, in a helpful way. They can think whatever they want about my lesser sophisticated way of drinking coffee but customers service shouldn't slip. Seriously, we aren't in France people, this is America and people like their coffee in many different ways, deal with it. 
Thank you, I feel so much better.
author: Heather D.

description:
Terrible service. Overpriced prices. The coffee I ordered was burnt. 
The croissant was not flakey and tasted old.
author: Leslie M.

description:
I love stopping by this cute Italian cafe whenever I'm shopping downtown. They have the BEST espresso and all of their staff is amazing. Super friendly and very efficient.

Try their chocolate brioche with your coffee next time! Delicious!
author: Kaitlin G.

description: Stopped by during my short stay in the 415 and had saw this place on yelp so I decided to stop by. Everything was great. Good was excellent, great service and overall a great location and a great view of the downtown area. I highly recommend it during your stay in San Francisco.
author: Aaron J.

description:
Iced coffee was ok, but would have been better if liquid sugar was available.  
Also had a chocolate croissant, and that was good, but nothing exceptional. 

Nice place to sit outside at Union Square for people watching!!!!
author: Erik B.

description: I live close by and this is my favorite cafe around. I always thought it was touristy (expensive & poor quality) since it's right inside Union Square, but I was wrong. Cafes and pastries are actually very good and price is just average in the area.
author: Mario I.

description:
Help!  There's lint in San Francisco's belly button!

If Union Square is San Francisco's belly button, Cafe Rulli Union Square is the lint.

It was an otherwise sunny day on Union Square, the tourists and residents were basking in glorious sunshine and all who came were here because Union Square represents the epicenter to our fair city.

This is a city known for its beautiful views, smashing architecture, smart people, sometimes odd but thoroughly adorable behavior and then there's our food and wine.

In fact, during this recently completed work week I spoke with people in New York, Austin and Seattle who were very much looking forward to their upcoming trips to San Francisco if only for the culinary bouquet on offer.

And right in the middle of my beloved home town, our epicenter, our belly button, Emporio Rulli Union Square taints this city's culinary reputation by serving dishes that have not benefited from neither heart or pride.

Yes, it is packed on a sunny day and if you want a bottle of foreign beer or a scone, Rulli has managed to not balls that up.

The one and only small consolation was that manager didn't charge us for taking one bite of our salad and wait staff were very nice, apologetic and leaving Rulli to work at a proper restaurant.

Do not patron Rulli lest you lust for lint.
author: Jay D.

description: Union square view and location is what the three stars are for. Ordered a cappuccino which was mediocre and the staff wasn't friendly. I ve had a mimosa here in the past which was pretty good. But meh for coffee.
author: Priyanka P.

description:
It was a gorgeous weekday with the sun shining and a light breeze every so often...we grabbed a table outside, soaked up the sun and people watched.  What a great way to enjoy a day off!

We started the day with:
Cappuccino - $3.15
Latte - $3.40
Bonjourno - $7.25 - breakfast sandwich with sausage and eggs - they heat it up with the panini press, so good
bomboloni with custard - $3.35 - not bad but can be better

Later in the afternoon, we had:
draft Peroni - $5.75
glass of Primitivo - $9.75
Tacchino - $7.75 - turkey sandwich, quite tasty
cup of soup - $3.6 - cream of vegetable, ok

I can sit there all day...
author: Gloria H.

description: Meh.  Pastry was cold, like refrigerator cold. Cappuccino was just Ok. Nothing like the Larkspur location.  We used to like this place. But, probably won't come back.
author: R D P.

description: 8 oz GELATO FOR ONLY $5! And in Union Square! Are you kidding me? I had a Hazelnut & was asked if I'd like some chocolate syrup drizzled on top-OH YEA! It was amazing!! I'm only giving 4 stars cuz I tasted my husbands brioche & it was a little dry. Overall, great stop for a sweet indulgence!
author: Kathleen P.

description:
Been there a half dozen time and never thought of yelping them but service has steadily declined here. 
The last time aside from getting attitude from the cashier I over hears the other counter person mocking this poor tourist couple. 
So I walked up and asked him if he was having a bad day. His response: I hate this $&)@ place. 
REALLY? then quite and save us all the grief. 
They need an on site manager bad. 

Hi
author: Marco M.

description:
5-star Venetian Hot Chocolate !!!!!

Make sure you order the churning Venetian hot chocolate on the counter, NOT the regular Hot Chocolate on the menu. 

The absolute BEST hot chocolate ANYWHERE!!!

I'll always stop by here when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Patrick Y.

description:
I asked for a small coffee but I was charged for a medium coffee.Reason - god knows.

I poured the coffee from the porcelain cup to the paper cup and showed to the person at the register.It was half of the paper glass sized small .

I asked the person at the register any reason why I was charged for the medium when the quantity was not even half the small paper cup.

The manager came.he mentioned that it is a misunderstanding.Surprisingly ,he did not want to pay me the difference.

It was not about the 50 cents difference here. It is about the attitude of the cafe.

Not sure ,why this happened to me, despite being a local person.
author: R P.

description:
+ in the middle of union square

+ / - decent paninis but i was hungry after a hour!
author: Margaret R.

description:
Food and coffee was good two days in a row, service personal were not good, specifically one person (woman) working the coffee machine.  

I will proceed to say she was rude and should probably look at a different profession!

Location is captive and reflects they do not need to be polite to customers!  What a colossal failure, the service and owners do not really get it!
author: William S.

description:
Good place to sit and have a coffee in union square.

This place is good - the people are friendly and the food is decent. Won't change your life though.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Emporia ruli is one of the first places my bf and I went to when we went to San Francisco. With that said we came here two more times after that since it was conveniently located on the corner of Union Square. This place had a perfect view of the festivities that were going on that afternoon and to straight up people watch. Let's face it there are some pretty interesting people in out there! We ordered a platter with an assortment of cheeses (blue cheese...one of my faves), a swirl of fresh honey, fresh bread slices, Kamlata olives, candied walnuts and artichokes which was pretty mediocre. We didn't only enjoy the two glasses of red wine we ordered but also the extra glass of wine that our waitress offered us since she accidentally poured it. The only downfall is that the prices don't reflect the quality of the food.
author: AshnAmy -.

description:
no. I do not want a gift card from you. your genetic response to my review demonstrates how little you guys care about customers.

you can't buy me with that, especially not after the harassment we endured.

NEVER GOING BACK.
author: Ara L.

description:
My hubby and I were actually looking for a Starbucks but wasn't able to find one within the vicinity, so we decided to give this place a try. This coffee shop sits right in the heart of downtown Union Square where there's lots of foot traffic - which means this coffee joint gets extremely busy. 

This place has definitely become our new spot for our all time favorite, hazelnut latte.  It has a very bold and flavorful aroma that is not too sweet like most other coffee shops - nor does it have that fake artificial flavor to it either. Surprisingly, this place not only serves coffee but you can also order a glass of wine right off the menu as well! There is also a pastry bar that appeared to be only the left overs during my evening visit. Those goodies did not look appealing at all...

This place is rather more upscale compared to your typical cafe. The employees were attired in white collar shirts and apron.  The staff is very friendly and well-mannered. There's indoor and outdoor seating available. Definitely a great spot to catch up with an old friend over coffee. 

We look forward to coming back during our next visit to SF!
author: Mei W.

description:
All I can say is, the Venetian Hot Chocolate! It's almost like drinking a melted chocolate bar, it's rich, it's hot, and it's delicious.

The best is going during  the winter, so you drink that cup while watching the ice skaters.  It's a very touristy  and busy area, so be ready for some crowds.
author: Nadeem A.

description:
*********************** REVIEW 436 ************************

          Located at Union Square, they open earlier than most coffee shops here on the weekend. The line was around the door at 10ish AM! Emporio Rulli offers coffee with pastries, charcuterie, cheese, sandwich, and Italian wines.

           Took my folks and nieces here for some early latte and hot chocolate before hitting the shops for mom. Dad was shocked how inexpensive for the latte and 3 hot chocolates, less than 10 bucks! Yup in Union Square! 

           My nieces love the classic Venetian hot chocolate maker they have here. I also love their location in the Marina as well! It's such a well-run business!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Im torn. Because it's in Union Square it has one of the best views of the park and is one of the greatest places to sit on a sunny day. Because it is in Union Square it's also one of the biggest shit shows of tourists and huge lines. Guess you can't win them all. Get a cold beverage on a sunny day and hope that you can grab one of the front row tables. They make fairly good sfogliatinas too if you need a snack. 3.5 stars
author: Kim N.

description:
Stopped in here for a Ham & Brie Sandwich on French bread. There was nothing special about it really, but it was quite nice and fairly priced for Union Square.

Location - 5 STARS
Service - 3 STARS
Food - 3 STARS
Value - 3 STARS
Ambiance/Decor - 4 STARS
author: John D.

description:
Here's my favorite line from Federico Fellini's "La Dolce Vita"...
"I'm too serious to be a dilettante and too much a dabbler to be a professional. Even the most miserable life is better than a sheltered existence in an organized society where everything is calculated and perfected."
...it's the kind of WTF comment you're likely to hear waiting in line here.

If you have a desire to become Eurotrash, motion your hands like Fellini and open your silk button-down shirt to your hirsute navel, by all means, this is the place for you. At least, that's the faux-fashionable type of customer that appears drawn to this glamorous kiosk...you know...the collagen-inflated woman with the perfect Buster Brown haircut...the hundred-dollar-bearing Italian tourist who orders one of everything in the extensive pastry case...the snippy, beret-headed ballet dancer who refuses to wait in line for his espresso...

As a lowly plebeian who buys his shirts at Target, I don't feel I belong here, a fact that was passively confirmed by the downward cast of the skinny server when I came up to order. I managed to overlook the self-inflicted snub and ordered a peach tart and a cup of coffee that totaled about $6. Guess what? The tart was actually delicious (look at the photo in the gallery). I sat outside on the patio, and a mime came up to me with a carnation. It was like a scene from "La Dolce Vita". Perhaps I am Eurotrash.

COFFEE/PASTRIES - 4 stars...flaky pastries and thick coffee...better than the other way around
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...a European-style plaza cafe does make a nice complement to Union Square
SERVICE - 3 stars...a tad snippy to me
TOTAL - 4 stars...not a place I frequent, but when I'm feeling pretentiously Continental, here I will be
author: Ed U.

description:
I love coming to Emporio Rulli especially because it's conveniently located on top of Union Square. I've been here quite a few times but the best of those were shared with my better half. We shared mochas and our absolute favorite: TIRAMISU!

In the middle of one of the busiest parts of San Francisco, the FiDi/Downtown of S.F. offers shopping, fine dining, local eateries, hot dog stands and entertainment. What I find is culture and where there is culture lies some sumptuous desserts & coffees!

Upside: For coffee and desserts, Emporio is a little pricey with a cup of coffee w/ a single shot averaging to $5+ and desserts starting at $3. You'll be able to feel the quality and love put into everything they offer at Emporio. Yes, they definitely do serve alcohol for those seeking something cold & refreshing after a long morning of shopping for the women and holding those shopping bags for the men (& vice versa). Buy a hot dog from Stanley's Steamers (located across the street in front of Macy's), buy a pint of your favorite and sit down to a good snack. 

Downside: The only thing that surprised me about this place was seeing a slice of prosciutto and three thinly sliced slices of cantaloupe on a large plate priced for $10. I guess it can work for those who are on meager mode. 

Either way, it's delicious; patrons will be able to reflect on their day, enjoy the brisk air, encounter a pigeon or two and can really enjoy some coffee in/outdoors and have a conversation without the hustle & bustle of a Starbucks.
author: Carol L.

description:
You're paying for location, but on a warmer night, or day - it's worth it.

Especially since the people watching here -  - an interesting mixture of tourists, weathered locals, and people who work in the area, is eventful. To say the least.

We stopped in here briefly and I ended up getting a mint Mighty Leaf Tea - and my cafe counterpart - got an orange soda and packaged brownie. The brownie was decent, and it's hard to go wrong with Mighty Leaf. The woman gave me an extra large cup - perfect for nursing outdoors - on  a concrete ledge - as I watched Union Square's magic unfold before me.

There are better, much cheaper sandwich and savory spots nearby - but as far as a decent pastry/dessert (though be warned that they are expensive) and a big cup of tea - goes -  Emporio Rulli is actually a pretty convenient and sweet spot.

Come here for the experience - and keep your expectations for the food - a little low - and you'll enjoy this place.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: I have been coming here since I was a kid. I usually get tea (I am not so much into coffee). But the highlight for many is their rich Venetian Hot Chocolate..yummmmmmm. During the winter months, you have a perfect view of the ice skating rink. Beware of the pigeons the rest of the year though. They are VICIOUS!
author: Ariel Z.

description:
Perfect place for an espresso and pastry while people watching on a Sunday.  

The capuccino and espresso was delicious, the pastry items were simply ok.  But, honestly, you are dining here for the enjoyment of being in the center of SF's shopping buzz, people watchin, and taking in the glory of the city.

Its a perfect place for a stop-over while shopping.
author: Natalie G.

description:
If I could give this place no stars, I would. 
However if you must go, AVOID worker: HUIQIANG. He's a jackass.
If you've read previous posts about the workers here and what horrible people they are, they aren't lying.
I went to this cafe on September 27th a little after 9 am, so manager, please do the math and fire this jackass who was working.
Upon standing in line, I was in back of two European men.
Now I get it, I work in customer service, foreigners can be a bit harder to deal with.
They ordered two chocolate brioche and two coffees on separate tabs.
The cashier moron proceeded to make this transaction a lot harder then it should have been, verbally stating his annoyance with them for the separate charges.
After they paid, he told them he'd call them when it was ready so they walked outside.
As soon as their items were finished, he proceeded to yell, at the top if his idiotic lungs, "Europe! Your food!" Multiple times to no avail.
Then finally he says, verbatim, "oh for fucks sake." 
Haha, what an impatient imbecile.
Finally I ordered. A fruit, parfait and a tea. $11.45. Already packaged in the case.
I got my tea and after the completion of the next two orders after mine I asked for my food. 
This jackass went on to tell me he didn't charge me for either food dishes!
Thank god for receipts!
Oddly, after producing mine, this IDIOT, still insisted that he didn't charge me! Then he starts tapping on the register, doing, god knows what, so I pointed at my receipt and reiterated loud and clear "fruit bowl and pafait, paid for." 
Then he tells me to wait on the side for my things, which I wouldn't at this point, before finally reaching over and handing them to me.
Avoid this place at all costs! It has the potential to be amazing, minus the jerk face named HUIQIANG.
author: Ella A.

description: Beautiful drinks. Fantastically delicate pastry choices. Everything was delicious and lovely and you simply cannot top the location on the square.
author: Alissa R.

description:
Really captures the European spirit: in flavor and environment.  

Ordered a small latte with a shot of vanilla syrup.  Not cheap @ $3.55.  But I just imagined a warm spring day in the middle of Union Square and it's worth every cent.  

The food and pastries looked tempting.  Service was surprisingly good.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Great location (heart of union square). Perfect for people watching. There was a nice selection of dessert options. The hot chocolate so rich almost bitter, but good.

Two dings though.. the coffee was not all that amazing and was overpriced. Also, the material used to make the cups and plastic water cups are very high quality which is great but not eco-friendly... I kept seeing people grab a plastic cup fill it half way with water and toss it in the trash (no recycling bin available). Pretty irresponsibly of a busy cafe to not offer recycling. Kinda left a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Nora N.

description: The customer service here is delightful everyone is very friendly and welcoming. I ordered the salmone panini. Which did not disappoint at all. I also ordered a latte which had pretty cool latte art. Definitely will come back to this cafe when I'm in the area.
author: Sisley C.

description: Draft Beer machine broken one day. Entire place shut down the next with no signage/reason why. Out of Perroni another day. Unfriendly service consistently. But what really annoys me is that they have these two prime locations on Union Square but treat that with such disrespect. I'm embarrassed for our City and the tourists that visit here.
author: Scott C.

description:
(See pic)

More of 3.5 stars.

Been here numerous times but didn't find anything special to write an update since it's just a very touristy place for coffee and tons of pastries and some sandwiches/salads. Coffee was actually quite decent and did not have a face punching taste.

But writing an update for the Cialde they make and package. $15.45 for 4 slices of Italian style waffle that are for desserts, which is great pairing with Vin Santo, gelato or zabaglione.
author: T L.

description:
I'm only giving this place an extra star because it's in a fantastic location and they do have good coffee/beverages. The service is terrible, the servers are not interested (I'm sure they probably have to deal with a lot of demanding tourists.) The food is HORRIBLE. Dry, stale sandwiches, wilty salads- it's never attractive when people outwardly tell you "I can't add or take off anything because everything is pre-made." As a San Franciscan, I know better but damn, it's convenient sometimes! 

If you're looking for a good place to people watch, def. have a drink (the pastries aren't that fresh either.) 

But if you're looking to have lunch somewhere decent, PLEASE go somewhere else.
author: Lianne Z.

description:
Bottom Line: A fun and beautiful place to people watch at Union Square while you play tourist and enjoy some good coffee and food.

On this visit, we only had a cappuccino and an iced tea, but they were good just the same.

This cafe is situated in the heart of Union Square, and it's well kept.  Tourists are everywhere, so it's fun to people watch.  

Have a coffee and a snack out here, and enjoy.
author: Anson G.

description:
My husband and I spent the day checking out the downtown holiday scene yesterday.  The weather was UGLY but we were troopers and still managed to enjoy the beautiful christmas decorations at Union Square.  It was pouring rain yesterday so we tried to stay dry by seeking shelter at the Emporio Rulli cafe at Union Square. 

 It was CROWDED in there.  I think everyone else had the same idea as us. 

I ordered a regular hot chocolate and my husband ordered coffee. 
I waited approximately 10 to 15 minutes for my small cup of hot chocolate.  It was kinda disorganized in there but I give it up to them - it was crowded!  Nice location and my hot chocolate was delicious but all in all this place was just OK.
author: Christine P.

description:
3.5 - Location location location. On one of the few sunny days in SF, this is one THE greatest spots to be - out on the islet called Union Square - you get a great view to people watch, soak in some sun, and just enjoy being in San Francisco. 

We were lucky enough to score a table with an umbrella. The Cafe is divided into 2 sections - self serve and full service. With self serve, you fend for yourself in finding a table, and fighting off the pigeons that stalk fallen bread morsels.

While the hot beverages and pastries were quite alluring, I decided to go  with something more substantial - the Breakfast Sandwich ($7) - egg frittata, bacon, and tomatoes on focaccia. The eggs were fluffy and light as a frittata should be. Big serving too, coming as a 4" x 8" rectangle sliced at a diagonal.

The Tacchino Panini ($7.50) was pretty good too. Saltier than the Breakfast Sandwich because of the good portion of smoked turkey and melted fontina cheese inside, not to mention the ciabatta bread. This was served with a small side salad. 

While the sandwiches weren't to die for, the location was. And there's free wi-fi. So if you can ignore the gaggle of tourists flocking with the pigeons, this could definitely be a relaxing spot to while away a few hours.
author: Cindy W.

description: I know I'm supposed to be too jaded to love a place situated in the middle of tourist hell. But, that said, the people watching was great. The coffee was perfect. The food was wonderful. And on a sunny warm afternoon, with good company, I was very, very happy here.
author: Morris R.

description:
If you're in Union Square and need coffee, Emporio Rulli might be a good stop.

I need coffee to try to stay awake for the show Spring Awakening.

I got a small cup of Iced Latte.  They charged $3.25 + .50 ice! = $3.75!  Evil small cup.

It was pretty good for coffee, not too bitter & kept me awake.  That's worth the extra charge I guess.

FREE water on the side near the door if you need it.
author: Ann L.

description: Walking through the business district on a nice day and thought I could use a nice drink outside.  Went into union square and saw this place.  I ordered a draft Peroni which was served up in a beautiful tall Peroni glass and enjoyed it overlooking the square.  Perfect little stop.
author: Robert P.

description:
A-ok! Emporio Rulli is conveniently located in Union Square and is perfect for those chilly nights in SF. The service was so-so, but I felt like that didn't matter because my boyfriend took our gingerbread lattes and hot apple cider to go. Their prices are reasonable and there's plenty of indoor and outdoor seating.

Hot Apple Cider - Delicious and perfect for a 37 degree chilly night! It was sweetened to perfection and really yummy.

Gingerbread Latte - I had a sip of this and didn't really care for it. My boyfriend enjoyed it, though.

Overall, Emporio Rulli is a good cafe with yummy drinks and pastries.
author: Joyce E.

description: We went here after ice skating on a lazy Sunday afternoon, seeing that it was the only not tourist-infested restaurant around Union Square. And it was EXPENSIVE. We paid $70 for 3 (small) pasta salads, a caesar salad, a tuna sandwich, and two drinks. $70. Yeah. The food was only so-so. The pasta salad was relatively small and very dry (and it was, like, 10 bucks). I have nothing against the tuna sandwich, except for that it was also very small (at least they were generous with the tuna). So that's it. Find yourself somewhere else to eat for less. (Unless you really want to avoid lines during tourist season.)
author: Anonymous R.

description: It's a nice cafe in the middle of Union Square it can be challenging to get a  table due to their location but their selection is great. Affogato was very good!
author: Angel J.

description:
This is a great place to have a drink or a snack while shopping in Union Square.  Well, it's an ok place. To be perfectly honest, if you're like me and you have a bird phobia, this is a horrible place to have a drink or a snack.  

If you're a pigeon, and you love free food and people watching, this is totally your spot.
author: Renee D.

description:
I stopped in Rulli's today, craving a chai latte. Service was fast and the food in the case looked very tempting. I was pleasantly surprised it wasn't overcrowded with tourists as usual. 
My chai was mostly foam and overly sweet, I could taste no cinammon or other spices. The worst part was that it was luke warm. I've been here before and have been satisfied with their coffee, but the chai just doesn't cut it.
author: Nastasia G.

description: As a big fan of Rulli's main location in Larkspur and their old Chestnut St cafe, during my last visit to SF I walked to Union Square in anticipation of a special breakfast. Despite the smaller variety of items offered at this location, the quality is still pretty good. Not quite at the same level is their customer service. Having more customers than tables is indeed positive for a business, a sign of success. However, it forces to make pesky decisions, like whether to give out numbers or assign tables only to parties that have all their people present. Rulli at Union Square decided to dispense with all these old school solutions and settled for a more revolutionary approach. Anyone, independently of their arrival time or position in line, can claim rights on a table by marking it with any available item. Today I was told by the staff that I had to eat standing because two tables were occupied by umbrellas and one by a bottle of water. I am not penalizing Rulli for choosing this rule, which obviously goes in the direction of increased democracy and gives everyone a chance, independently of untolerable privileges to which people who arrived earlier feel entitled. However, I must lower my rating due to their failure to inform the customers on the best strategies to win a table. My suggestion to future patrons is to bring a deck of cards and swiftly launch them on any available table as soon as they enter the door. This way one can beat any other customer trying to walk to the table to leave some paraphernalia on it before joining the line. Some of those sticky hand-shaped children toys should work even better.
author: Marco D.

description: Never thought the coffee would be as good as it actually was. The place is small so I took it to go, but the coffee was delicious!
author: Chela S.

description: overpriced, bland and unorganized! went there with friends to grab a drink before shopping. ordered a 12 oz hot chocolate and then waited for my drink at the window. the barista never called my name so I did not know my drink was ready.. when I walked up to the window there were 3 drinks there and when I tried to ask what these were he said he was busy! finally after serving out a few drinks he said they were hot chocolate & he'd make us a new one.. ok thanks! but when I finally got to drink it, it was more warm milk than hot chocolate! never going here again!!
author: JA A.

description:
Food - 1 star
Service - 3 stars
Dog friendly - 5 stars

Bacon and egg breakfast sandwich - the bacon was super fatty and limp.  The bread was so dry it fell apart into a heap of crumbles. $7+ for this?!

Turky panini -  Crispy outside but still cold in the middle. $7+ for this?!

Josie poodle concurred with my assessment by pooping in the planter. My apology to the tourists from Canada sitting on the other side!
author: Kim W.

description: This place wasn't what I remembered it to be, at least not this time. My latte was still quite good, but the lively feel of my (formerly) favorite SF coffee place had gone the way of the dodo. The staff were very friendly with each other, but less so with paying customers.  My coffee saucer was dirty, as was the sugar/milk station.  I ordered a ham and cheese croissant which was pretty good.  The cheese was nice and melty but sadly the croissant was burnt. I guess I'll take the good with the bad, as the espresso drinks outclass Starbucks by a mile.
author: Alex H.

description: Besides the expensive drinks they have, the food is surprisingly good. It's good for a light snack during the day or for a quick one during a small break.
author: Sanish S.

description: $8.5 for a tiny glass of sangria? And all they did was pour it from a plastic jar? And they didn't even bother to bring it to your table? Hell no. Don't even bother to try this place unless you wanna be ripped off.
author: Javier S.

description:
This coffee is probably the best I've had at any food service establishment.  Strong, smooth, well-balanced, barely acidic.  This is just the regular house blend.  Your 2nd refill is free and the 3rd refill is only .65 cents.  I had the Espresso and Americano (on two occasions), a sour cherry pastry (i need that sour cherry in a jar) and a biscotti-like cookie (for dunking).  OJ is pucker-sweet fresh and sandwiches (which suspiciously seem to be a culinary students' version of the Egg McMuffin) are assembled between homemade sliced bread.  I don't recommend the sandwiches.  Go for the drinks and pastries.  The whole menu is crazy affordable for being ground zero in tourist territory.

The location is a terrific place to people watch on a sunny day.  Maybe it was because I was on vacation but the people seemed friendlier, nicer and happy.  If the view from where I was sitting could've been frozen in time and the imagery in the capable hands of a neo-impressionist, it could've easily have been in a John Hughes film.  (Big ups to the 80s!!)
author: Sarah K.

description:
Walking through Union Square today around 2 PM after a fantastic facial, I decided to stop at Emporio Rulli for a late lunch.  Bad idea - the horrible service completely ruined my post-facial high.  It started with Huiqiang at the register.  The guy couldn't be bothered with helping customers.  I asked for a Tacchino sandwich (he didn't offer to add a salad), a decaf cappuccino and a pan dolce cookie.  Huiqiang asked, "Which pan dolce?" (is there more than one in the case?) but didn't bother to follow me when I went to show it to him in the case.  Then he gave me a number for the sandwich that was being heated and grilled and told me to wait for my coffee.  The guy with the sandwich was ready before my coffee so he went looking for my number.  I stopped him and let him know that I'm waiting for my coffee.  Seeing me carrying 2 bags, my pan dolce and receipt, he proceeds to hand me my sandwich on a plate.  I told him that I need help carrying the sandwich because I needed one free hand for my coffee and pointed to a table outside.  He said he didn't want to take my sandwich outside and risk the birds taking it.  I asked if 1) he could wait a couple minutes until I get my coffee so we could walk out together or 2) I'll take the sandwich and he can bring me my coffee when it's ready.  He said, "No, I can't do that."  What?!?  CAN'T bring me coffee?  Is the guy on a leash that prevents him from walking more that 10 feet from the cafe?!?  It was 2 PM and no other customers inside the cafe!  Even more ridiculous was another employee sitting in an interior corner table who laughed and rolled his eyes as if to say, "yeah, the crazy things customers ask for."  To top it all off, the guy behind the counter hands me my cappuccino and says, "uh, thank you" implying that I was a difficult/rude customer.

The whole staff couldn't care less about customers much less providing service.  Glad I didn't tip but really wish I hadn't given them my business at all.  

As for the food, it was ok - certainly not worth putting up with the poor service and attitude of the staff.

RECOMMENDATION:  Enjoy the square but get your coffee, sandwich or snack elsewhere and grab a seat on the steps or chairs around the park.  Rulli is not worth the demeaning hassle.
author: Tone C.

description: The iced coffee is pretty good here, and what's even better: taking that iced coffee and sitting out in Union Square, particularly on a wonderful, warm, sunny day.  I could have sat there all day if work wasn't calling.  Great spot to soak it up for some alone time, or grab a friend and hang out.
author: Mel G.

description:
You know, its a tourist spot, yet, there's quality in what is sold here.

This has become a meet-up spot for me. We always get sangria. No matter how packed Union Square is, the impact at the Emporio Rulli is handled well by the bartenders and waitresses running the show. It never is complicated finding a table either. Even in the middle of Union Square!

It's definitely a place to sit at and think to yourself "Am I really here?" and as you look around and see photographers taking photos you just enjoy it.

Lately, every restaurant I walk into has been in a philanthropist mood. I got pasta the other day. I don't even know what kind of pasta it was, but it was great and we never ordered it, but they gave it to us anyway, now I know of another good spot to get pasta around here.
author: Alexia R.

description:
Came here for a casual business meeting for coffee. 

Had a soy latte, and it was honestly one of the best I've ever had. Outdoor seating was great, and really beautiful. Having a cup of coffee, sitting in the sun in the middle of San Francisco's Union Square? What else can you ask for?

I'll have to come back for lunch one day and try out their food.
author: Jon C.

description:
DRINK:
1.) Vanilla Latte

ATMOSPHERE:
It's right in Union Square! Perfect for enjoying a Sunny Sunday afternoon to watch all the people pass by or others also enjoying the square. So it's nice to have a cafe here. And they sell beer and wine! It's kinda like a big kiosk, no bathrooms inside, very few seating inside.. just buncha tables and chairs outside. Table service section and also regular cafe seat yourself section. And oops, I thought this place was called il caffe, since that's what the signs say. But I guess that's ... Italian? for the cafe?

4/4/2011
author: Angela L.

description: The wine and outside atmosphere was perfect. You couldn't ask for a nicer day in San Francisco. The service on the other hand was something to forget. The server kristyn just seems unhappy.
author: Tim D.

description:
Union Square has always been a great location in search of an identity - over the years it's been redesigned several times, and today it's tiered piazza appearance invites people to come hang out and take in the heart of the city. Helping make the new square much more enjoyable is Emporio Rulli, nicely located on the eastern edge of the square so that you can sit outside and take in the sun on a beautiful day.

Location is without question Emporio Rulli's best asset, but its selection of light fare, desserts, and drinks are ideal for times you want to meet up with a friend, loved one or date for a casual experience. None of what I've had here rocks my world, but it's usually good enough to keep me satisfied and coming back. 

Service can at times be slow - one would think that any owner placing a cafe in one of the busiest tourist areas in the western United States would realize that they are best served getting people in and out quickly, so be ready to wait in line for 5-10 minutes. (In fairness, the building is quite small so there's only so much staff they can add, but still...)

Overall I recommend this place. You're not going to have a religious experience because of amazing desserts or outstanding service, but you should end up having a nice, relaxing time in the midst of downtown.
author: Gregg G.

description:
Emporio Rulli I heart you.

When I first moved up to SF in 2003, I fell in love with this place.  Even though I worked for the green apron company at the time, when I came to down town, I came to Union Square to take in and embrance SF. 

I'd bring a book and order:

Ristretto Hazelnut Doppio, a San Pell and whatever pastry looked good that day (usually a chocolate brioche).

For a good strong 3-4 years the staff had it down and already knew what I wanted, from a staff change and management change every 3 or so years, I would come sparingly, the ambiance has totally changed plus you can't smoke on the Square anymore.  It's definitely not the same.  I was originally going to give Emporio Rulli a 4, but because someone telling me what I can and can not do with my life, I'm taking a star back, other than that, I heart Rulli.
author: Edrian D.

description: Couldn't find parking at Brenda's this morning and already a line out the door and it wasn't even 10 yet.  We wound up at this tourist spot and although I have no regrets, it wasn't my first choice for a reason.  Overpriced chocolate croissant and ham/egg/cheese panini.  I wasn't surprised that it was but I did not enjoy paying $20+ dollars for 2 smallish pastries, a regular coffee and a latte.  It would've been a 2-star performance except my son really enjoyed sitting there and watching the birds (or as he calls them, the 'boyds') and the ice skaters--yes, the rink is still up.  The food was alright, the coffee much better.  So many other breakfast choices in the city so skip this cafe if you can help it.
author: Joc V.

description: There are two sections to this cafe. One with full table service and the other where you place your order at the counter and sit down and wait til it is delivered. That generally works for me. The operation runs smoothly and the food is tasty and attractively presented. I can't find a single fault with this place which occupies the best real estate in Union Square.
author: Paula H.

description:
Went to this coffee shop because we were walking around in the city and wanted to take a coffee break.  The thing about this place is that it's the ONLY coffee shop in Union Square and so you're FORCED to go there.  It's not too hard to make a decent cup of coffee - so my iced coffee wasn't horrible, but if anything there was horrible, it was definitely the service.  

After finding a table inside, we stood by the table and sat down to the DIRTY table and waited almost 15 minutes before we were able to get anyone to come and clean it.  And if anything, "cleaning the table" to them meant taking away the dishes and wiping the crumbs onto the floor... yech!

The place isn't the best for cold drinks - they do nothing "blended" (maybe I'm just too spoiled by Starbucks and Coffee Bean), and if you want it cold, they just put it on ice.  Our order was two iced coffees and one iced tea.  The iced coffee's came with no problems, but it seems that there was maybe a communication barrier when we mentioned "iced tea".  Though it clearly states iced tea as a menu item, it seemed as though no one ever ordered it.  The tea came hot in a mug, when asked for the iced tea, they simply provided a large glass of ice.  When we had asked the server to add the tea and the ice, he was about to pour the cup of ice into the FULL mug of HOT tea - not brilliant.  

We had also ordered a chocolate croissant and a regular croissant - both were pretty tough to eat.

I'd definitely think twice about going to this coffee shop again!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Union square is very famous for the luxurious stores like Gucci, Louis Vuitton, Macy's, etc... 
On the South-East corner of Union square at Geary and Stockton, you can find a little Italian café, called RULLI, where you can take a break after a long day of shopping. On a sunny day, you can enjoy  their terrace and the little art gallery next to the cafe. Without the noise of the street and the pigeons which perturb your relaxation time, this place could be very peaceful and calm.

The cafe gives you a large choice of drinks as hot drink (coffee, hot chocolate, tea), soda, juce or if you want it is possible to have a glass of wine. If you are hungry, you can take brunch at RULLI. They serve very fresh salads or Paninis. If you have a little hunger, you will enjoy their pretty stand of food inside of the cafe. Their prices are reasonable for a cafe in this place of the town. Inside of the building, the counter is in disarray with bottles of wine, foods, plates...
The waiters look very clean and professional. Every time you will be sure to be serve by someone because you will often find a waiter on the terrace.

For me this place has a lot of good advantages. I recommend it for drinks with friends, take a break or after a meeting. Enjoy it !
author: Valentine F.

description:
1.IL Caffee RULLI is located at Union Square at Stockton and Geary St..
2.The coffee shop services both inside and outside seats.
3.There is a gallery nearby the coffee shop every Tuesday.
4.Also, there are so many boutique fashion stores like Gucci and Tiffany&Co around the coffee shop.
5.So many people enjoy talking and taking a break on their free time.
6.The products of the coffee shop are quick and delicious.
7.Even though it is the coffee shop,you can have beer,tea,breakfast and lunch.
8.The price is a little bit expensive,but the service is very good,especially the juice is fresh.
9.The transportion around this shop is busy.
10.A lot of vistors come to the coffee shop.
11. I really like this place because I could talke it easy after my school. 
I stongly recommend this coffee shop because this is the most relaxing place downtown.
author: CHUNG CHE C.

description: I'm a fan of the hustle and bustle of Union Square. This place is right in the center of it. It takes a REALLY long time to get your coffee, but it's full bodied and delicious. The out door seating is great.
author: Mahta P.

description:
Seems like the majority of yelpers are quite fond of this place.
So am I. NOT.

While the location was quite darling (Union Square) and was almost out of an Audrey Hepburn movie, the place lacked any sort of charm.

First off, they had almost nothing to eat. Mind you it was like 11am, how do you run out of the majority of food? Oh that's right, it's all pre-made.

Cashiers were rude. VERY RUDE. I understand that I came off rather exhausted since I had a long night, but I smiled because I was hungry and nothing makes me happier than coffee and food. I asked simply if something can be altered and before I finished he snapped 
"IT'S PRE-MADE!"......Oh my bad, I should have known better since I'm a card carrying club member.

Anyways, he forgot my apple juice and instead of being nice I just asked bluntly  "my apple juice?"  He grabbed it and slid it across the counter,no apology, but I carried on.

Sat outside with my group of friends and food came out slowly but surely. Sadly 2 plates didn't come out at all. We asked if one of the umbrellas could be taken down, never happened either, we were told frankly that one of the dishwashers will get it....even though he clearly was a bus boy. 

One of the girls finally asked for a manager, who took forever to come out and when she did, she was just as rude. She demanded to see reciepts for the missing food and then when being approach for another question....she interrupted with 

" I'M BUSY. LOOK AT THE SWEAT COMING DOWN MY FACE!"
That's not only rude but plain gross. 
She brought out the plates and one was wrong, oh well free fruit.
Finally everything was out...she was gone, with no formal apology.

The food was bland,really bland, almost soggy  and the salad was wilted.COFFEE was excellent, I'm pretty sure they have better drinks than food. 
Maybe we caught them on a really off day? oh well, it was definitely an unpleasant experience,  customer service really defines an experience ( I've been a server for 4 years and counting) I might give it another try, we shall see.

FYI= Pigeons seriously stake out the tables, the minute you get up they come like an army, almost like a scene from The Birds movie, I'd advise you to run and run fast.
author: Liz C.

description: having breakfast early in the morning at rulli's brings me a diffrerent perspective of union square, no bustling crowd, no undesirable traffic noise, just fresh air and a calming peace of mind, i like to take my time and enjoy my cup of latte and croissant and let my mind goes blind for a while , sometimes simplicity brings out the pleasure of life.
author: Jerry S.

description:
Emporio Rulli likes to occupy only a particular type of location.  Locations that are tourist ridden and somewhat isolated in terms of other dining options.  Locations like Union Square and the international terminal at SFO.  

For this reason, they like to rape their customers.  Everything here is below average, and WAY OVERPRICED. My normal, every day small iced soy latte at the Union Square location is $5.05, and at the airport it's over $6.  And what really irks me is at both locations, they don't have simple syrup at the condiments bar, so I can never sweeten my iced drink properly.  When I recommended they begin carrying some, I received a curt and apathetic reply from one of the employees: "Yea, that's already been recommended. Thanks."  For a $5 espresso drink, I think they should offer some freakin' simple syrup to their customers, like almost all other coffee shops do.

In addition, the food is pre-made, nothing special, and obviously, very overpriced.
author: Genevieve M.

description: For the location , it was better than expected. Still overpriced for below average food (sandwiches are tiny although I enjoyed my tiny milanese sandwich...the bonjourno my bf got had limp old looking cheese and pre-packaged sausage. However, as said previously, the location is prime and I expected even more skyrocketed prices and even lower quality food. Doesn't mean you can't make your food awesome though....
author: Anne C.

description: The setting is gorgeous: prime location right ON union square.  Outside of that my panini was average.  It arrived at my table lukewarm.  My friend got a beet and goat cheese salad, which was pretty tasteless.  Definitely, not "a-ok" -- thus the 2 stars.  This place is much better for beers than food so depends what you're looking for.  Feels like they are catering to tourists who don't know any better and maybe don't read yelp.  Definitely not recommended for a lunch spot.
author: Rob E.

description:
Glad to see something in Union Square is open early while I'm waiting for the 30 or 45 bus to get to work.  So yeah, walked in, grabbed a coffee, and bolted out to see if my bus arrived - and it was there... whoohooo!

12oz coffee = $2.05
author: Limzer L.

description:
I was here with my family for an after lunch coffee. After hunting for tables and waiting in line for about 10 minutes, we managed to order the pastries, coffee, tea and hot chocolate.

After getting most of our order, I had to wait 15 minutes till I got my hot chocolate! Even after asking multiple times and getting reassurance that I'm getting it, it wasn't until we started yelling that this is unacceptable that someone grabbed a paper cup, poured some syrup and milk in it and gave it to me. It was horrible. After some more complaining he manager sent us away with a cookie.

The coffee was okay, nothing special. The pastries a bit dry, again nothing special. I wouldn't recommend this place even for sitting around Union Square, unless you just want to sit outside with some mediocre beer.
author: Peter F.

description:
I like the convenience of the location because after a tiresome two-hour wait in line for a meet-and-greet and shopping I wanted to grab a quick bite.  It's a good spot to grab-n-go and find a spot around Union Square to eat your food (if weather permits).  I got the Tacchino turkey panini- plain, simple, and somewhat small for a $7.50 sandwich that comes with no sides.  But I loved how it was hot off the panini press. 

Know what you want quick because it gets crowded in the tiny place and you'll feel rushed.
author: Lisa C.

description: HOLY NAME CHANGE, BATMAN!    - Place was cool, quick and efficient....  but this is not the name of the place, it has changed....   Decent place to grab a coffee before exploring the city....  Nice start in Union Square~  :)
author: Dean P.

description:
I once spent a lovely afternoon at Emporio Rulli with my mother, sipping espresso and munching on pastries in the sun. I returned last week for a solo lunch only to be confronted with sub-par food and bored service.

I ordered the caesar salad with grilled chicken. The dressing, parmesan, and croutons were sparse, and the chicken was of the most bizarre texture - what I can only describe as gooey and chewy. I kept checking to make sure it was actually cooked and not raw in the center. I also ordered a bellini, which was so thick and sludge-like, I questioned whether there was even any prosecco accompanying the peach nectar. 

My server seemed annoyed by my presence and tried to rush me out quickly. The only redeeming value of the meal was its convenient location in Union Square, affording the opportunity to people-watch in the sun. 

I thoroughly enjoyed my first experience here last year, but now understand why Emporio Rulli is overrun with tourists, who simply don't know any better.
author: Britt M.

description: Excellent place to have coffee and pastry. The staff is also nice. Try the caramelized brioche (the staff calls it the crown jewel).
author: M Z.

description:
I have an unexpectedly fond memory of this touristy cafe- breakfast at Emporio Rulli was the end to a long and arduous adventure. The premise: My fiance and I had walked past some dive named David's Delicatessen awhile back, and we were intent on going back into SF to give its "highly-touted" breakfast (so the window sign read) a try. 

So Saturday morning, we get up at 8am and trek our way into SF damn skipping sure that we know exactly what we we're getting into w/o first consulting Yelp... or a map. At 9:30am, we're still looping endlessly through SF, wandering in and out of the Tenderloin, gingerly avoiding crackos and be-slippered hobos, working ourselves into a grump. 

At 10am, fiance suggests that we perhaps settle for a different deli/cafe- perhaps Peet's? Or Starbucks? I flat out refuse. Aside from walking past 10 or 15 different Starbucks, (all within 20 blocks of each other, all mocking me with their carbon copy signs displaying frothy holiday drinks) I want to go some place new. Some place "different." After all, I've just walked who-knows-how-many-miles of rolling SF hills; I don't want another Costco scone. 
 
We end up at Union Square for a break and- well what do you know! There's a cafe right on the square! The crowd looks schmoozy and international, and the architecture suggests bad food, but we're hungry & not-so-hot ourselves (what with the sweat from the walk.) We order two cups of coffee and two pastries, and the total comes to --brace yourself-- a mindblowing $18. 

$18. For a pair of coffee & pastries. 

Sneaky sneaky, guys... Not listing the prices of each food item next to their displays. Kindof a mean-spirited way to take advantage of the customer who doesn't want to appear gauche by asking for a price tag. You got me (finger guns). 

Long story short, the coffee was decent and the pastries were stale. Did I mention I paid $18 for the privilege? But maybe that's not the point. Maybe the point is the lovely scenery atop Union Square, appreciation of the rare San Francisco sun poking its head out from behind Karl the Fog, the ice skaters in the winter, the artists setting up their booths in the summer. 

Anyway, I later found out that David's Deli is rated an impressive 1.5 stars on yelp (dodge a bullet there, at least) and learned my real lesson: Bring a sandwich and enjoy the free view.
author: Tianyi S.

description: Great location and about what you can expect for decent coffee drinks. However tables are not bussed often enough and probably hosts one of the most unfriendly & miserable barista teams I've ever seen. Too many coffee options out there to support this place.
author: Bryce C.

description: 1 star for service, 2 stars for the coffee, and 5 for the location. Nuff said!
author: Gaurav A.

description:
I love the fact that people are on here complaining that this place is touristy and expensive and that's a downside.  It's in Union Square, people!! (Of course it's touristy and slightly more expensive than usual.)

It's a cute little coffee place with delicious looking pastries (I can't eat them because I eat gluten-free) and has great cappuccino!  It's also very convenient to visit before a long walk across the city.  Love it, will be back  next time I'm in the city.
author: Meghan C.

description:
This place has great sweet/savory pastries & cake slices. everything I've tried as been fresh and on point!! I'm big on good iced tea and there's is really good. plus great location to grab a light lunch/snack after shopping til you drop in union square. 

My boyfriend and I ordered a couple of iced teas and i had a simple but fresh bitter almond sticky round pastry. pillowy inside, mildly bittersweet outside, my boyfriend however went all out with one of their berry cake slices, this one started off with a white cookie-like crust then there was a creamy layer, a creamy berry layer (my favorite layer), and another layer of the cream. then a thin layer of pillowy white cake, another type of cream on top of that, then finally a beautiful arrangement of strawberries, blackberries, blueberries, and raspberries. divine
