the thing i like most about this place is you get what you pay for. there's nothing worse then stepping into a nice bakery and seeing all of their beautiful displays of pastries, cakes and goodies and to splurge (not only from the wallet, but of the waistband) for a treat only to take a bite and its STALE! that doesn't happen here! and i really appreciate that. 

this place is also a prime for people watching! the highlight: at 1:30pm on a Tuesday there were (i counted) 10 tables of single dining middle aged women here each with a spinach salad and a glass of wine (and yes there were refills).. seriously people on a freakin TUESDAY! ha ha not only the bums get sloshed before 2p midweek.
author: Kristin M.

description:
This place is over priced. A small cookie cost $3.35 with no taste. A cup of Grande Latte costs $4.80 which is also just OK.

The table is cramped and very dirty. The waiter only come to clean it when they feel you sit too long and should leave.
author: Chun L.

description:
Europe in the middle of San Francisco? (minus the sweater tied around the neck and the soccer jersey top)

The staff was great as were the options in the food case.  I find that coffee shops have too many sweets and not enough savory.  This place had friggin lasagna just below the croissants.  Awesome!

The coffee wasn't bitter and plenty hot.  Most of the people inside were speaking different languages.  No restrooms, by the way.

Don't half step.  Come here to kill time and enjoy Union Square.
author: Brendon D.

description: Well, they have tap beer and people watching. How bad can it be?
author: Maximillian M.

description:
This place is conveniently located in Union Square and yesterday the weather was nice so it was crowded.  My friend and I had decided to stop and take a load off to figure out our next move as we enjoyed "girl time in the city"  I spoke to a gentleman in the long line who told me that this was a family owned business started by immigrants and that he thought the baked goods were out of this world. 

They served Mighty Leaf teas which is pretty exciting! I ordered earl gray tea for my friend and a chai for myself as well as an intriguing little pastry that had hazelnut in the description.  The young man putting the tea bags in the cups was told by me and by the woman taking orders that it was earl gray and chai at least two times each and he still managed to put an English breakfast bag in one of the cups...? 

Once my friend got her head around her new flavour of tea, we sat in union square and watched children play and adults interact for more than an hour just talking and catching up.  It was delightful and the pastry was pretty yummy too!

This place has the potential for greatness as it is so well located with quality wares...the busy-ness seemed to affect the IQ of the help but I have to say the overall experience was very nice!
author: Liz F.

description: Great coffee and pastries and with the outdoor seating right in union square you can't go wrong.
author: Scott G.

description: This is definitely a tourist spot. But its a good one. I probably wouldn't make my way here with regularity, but... is a great spot to stop for a beer and a salad on the walk home from work. I've had the caprese salad and the cheese platter (shared). both were good, and worth the $9-12 price. Service was good/average. they were busy but they got around to us and the many tables that were there in fine time. i wouldn't recommend it as a 4 or 5 star place, its just a counter and a patio, but it is a patio (which is hard to find in SF),  the manger was very friendly, and the experience was good for locals and... tourists.
author: Adam X.

description:
The Venetian hot chocolate is worth a special trip.

Just remember to ask for it by name.  When I first went and simply requested "hot chocolate" I got a good but no better than anywhere else hot chocolate.  They didn't ask if I wanted their specialty, so I had to make a second trip.  (Not good salesmanship, folks.)

Yes, you can consume the Venetian hot chocolate with a spoon.  It's that thick.  Get it without whipped cream to keep it hotter longer.  The whipped cream just gets in the way anyway.

They open at 7:30 a.m. seven days a week.  

The baked goods I have had are nothing special, and are expensive ($3.35).  Oddly, a few items in their food case have price cards, the rest don't.  I had to ask to find out that a tiny sandwhich is $7.50.

And note that you will be charged $4.55 for a small cup that is only two-thirds full of hot chocolate.  For that price, they really should fill the cup.

If there is better hot chocolate anywhere in SF, I want to know about it.  Now.
author: Bay G.

description:
The perfect downtown spot for a cup of coffee while pondering life with a friend and taking in the ambiance of Union Square all while being serenaded by a homeless guy singing B.o.B's Airplanes.

A quintessential San Francisco afternoon.
author: Jason B.

description:
location location location.  on a bright sunny day, who wouldnt want to sit in the middle of union square and enjoy a drink and a pastry?  perfect for people watching and relaxing after shopping.  

i had the strawberry shortcake and the cake in the middle was stale and dry. but the weather!
author: claudia y.

description:
Ok this place is pretty cool.  I was walking to Saks and decided to check out this place.  My latte was the way I like it good and strong.  I was drawn to this rice-like pastry that turned out to be heaven.  The name of it was rather complicated so I apologize for not knowing wtf it was.  One thing I noted was that you pay $.75 premium for coffee drinks than your garden variety Starbucks.  But hey, this one has beer and wine!  

This place actually gets 3 stars plus one star for the cool location.  You can see kids ice skate and laugh at the adults falling.
author: Rob Y.

description: One of my favorite places for Italian pastries.  Torta de la Nonna, filled with custard and chocolate.  Oh, and don't eat the Cannoli, save them for me!
author: Arlene C.

description:
Pros:

+ 1 star for its awesome location, smack dab in the middle of Union Square.
+ 1 star for the option of outdoor seating, which is lovely for people-watching on a sunny day.
+ 1 star added for its pretty kick-ass cappuccino, which hit the spot after some hard-core shopping.

Cons:

- 1 star for its chaotic atmosphere inside.
- 1 star for its long lines and wait (just as bad as a Starbucks).

We're left with 3 stars for this little cafe...
author: Nina B.

description:
As has been stated, the location is key.  And with meager options in the vicinity, it is a likely choice I will even return to.  

I ordered a brioche, and they gave me an almond brioche.  Mistake.  I ate it anyway because I was halfway through it before I ran into the puddle of almond-sugar.  The brioche itself was unfortunately weak, a little stale, and reminding me of a pre-packaged product.

I ordered an espresso because they use cheap milk that was unattractively in gallon bottles on the back rack.  The cashiers seamed beat.  There were no seats outside available (location, remember?).  So I sat inside.  The place is attractively built inside and out, and I never feel rushed, once I find a seat.  

The espresso was 'meh'.  Very dark roast took all the flavor out of the bean, and it was syrupy when it should have been frothy.  Tasted good when your totally famished.

Without any reasonable competitors, I may return if I find myself in the area.
author: Marc M.

description:
Pricey, pricey, pricey...

But still I was pleasantly surprised from a recent visit here.  I tried one of their entree salads, a rather large serving of baby arugula, beets, goat (?) cheese and walnuts dressed in a light vinaigrette.  It was new, delicious and quite filling!  I forgot the name of it - Insalata di Something OMG It's GOOD, Try It!

Really.

After wolfing that down, I attacked an apple strudel and coffee.  Nice big slice.  The filling had some consistency of marzipan with apple chunks and nuts that was thick enough to earn the adjective "meaty".  But I still liked it.  You need a knife to help you eat one.

Overall, I think if the prices weren't so steep (knocked a star down for the prices) Emporio Rulli would be a good place for a splurge lunch.

Get that salad - it's worth it.
author: Eileen P.

description: I'm not a food handler extraordinaire but I knew when I saw all the milks out on the counter on a warm day and the Barista not using a thermometer to check the milk temperature as it was steamed, that this place was bad news. I ignored my instinct and drank my luke-warm latte while people watching on a beautiful day in Union Square. Unfortunately, within 2 hours, my beautiful SF day was ruined. I've now been confined to my house as my body turns itself inside out. I would not wish this day upon my greatest enemy. Do yourself a favor and stay far away. Head over to one of the many surrounding Coffee Beans, Satrbucks, Pete's, anywhere. I wish I had. Save yourself the horror.
author: Heather U.

description: 2 stars for location on a sunny day. Annoyed at rude staff member who practically threw our food on the table and turned to leave without explaining which sandwich was which (they all looked very much alike). I asked if the server would bring out our coffees to the table and was told no - I had to go inside to wait for them. Apparently it is ok to leave my hot sandwich outside to get cold while I wait 10 mins inside for the coffee. Can I please have my tip back?
author: Maz S.

description: We had breakfast here on a Sunday morning and it was absolutely lovely. We sat outside under an umbrella and had a great time just enjoying coffee, pastry, salad and sandwich. Their latte is absolutely delicious and so were the other dishes. One star off because most of the day this place is just too busy -- but we got there at 9:30 and had no problem.
author: Guido v.

description: Great location, delicious espresso drinks, yummy paninis, tasty pastries, friendly staff.  What more can i ask for on a sunny Sunday afternoon?
author: Yvette F.

description:
I like that this place is literally on Union Square- but quite frankly its overpriced and not that great.
The paninis are all pre-made somewhere and brought over to the cafe so all they have to do is grill them- say goodbye to any customer requests or alterations to anything.
author: Janell D.

description: I love this place.  I love their food, their coffee and teas.  I love their views of the Union Square.  I came here for breakfast again, but was disappointed.  I placed my order for coffee and a ham & egg sandwich.  Got my coffee and the number for my sandwich.  I sat outside to enjoy the beautiful Christmas tree and the ice skating rink activities with my number placed on my table.  30 minutes went by and no one from the café brought my sandwich to me nor to check on me to give me an update on my sandwich.  My coffee was cold and the sandwich was still not ready.  Finally I waved to one of the staffs for attention (took awhile), a waiter with blond spiky hairstyle came over and immediately apologized without me telling him what I calling him over for.  He immediately informed me that their printer was stuck and stopped printing.  He noticed the number on my table and asked what I was waiting for.  I felt upset before I called him over for the long wait of my sandwich, but due to his good customer service and the willingness to take care of the problem for me, I felt less upset.  He quickly brought my sandwich out.  I asked him for a new cup of hot coffee.  He quickly brought me a cup of hot coffee to enjoy with my hot sandwich.  I tipped him even when I was kept waiting for longer than usual for my sandwich.  He deserves the tip for taking care of the customer/me.
author: Gina W.

description: The location is fantastic. The workers were friendly and I had a pleasant view of the square itself. There are two locations, one on either side of the square, and they serve different foods. The location near Powell street sells more larger items, packaged foods, and easier to make coffee drinks. The main location, near Post street, sells Sandwiches, pastries, Gelatto, and many types of pastries. The building was clean and the service was fast. I'd say if you were going to go for a small lunch while shopping in the city, this is the place to go.
author: Alexander S.

description:
The downside: Everything looks better than it actually tastes. Well, I guess a wilted salad doesn't really look good in the first place. Stick to beverages.

The upside: It's almost impossible to not start talking to a stranger. If it's mingling you're seeking, or at least people watching, this is a great spot. 

The secret you need to know: VENETIAN HOT CHOCOLATE. So rich, so decadent, so totally making me gain those unwanted holiday pounds. 

I almost always stop by to grab a cappuccino and take a shopping break, hoping some impeccably dressed attractive man will try to chat me up.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
Let's face it, this cafe is a no brainer if you're looking for eye candy. Unfortunately, aforementioned eye candy is typically A) with their Euro counterpart or B) so busy figuring out how to order they don't even so much as glance your way. Still, eye candy plays a valuable role in a single girl's life, so props to Emporio Rulli for holding it down.

Obviously, I want to like this cafe not only because of their attractive patrons, but because it really does have all of the ingredients for success. It has outdoor seating for people-watching, a wine menu, espresso machines and panini makers. Today, my cappuccino was good, but my salmon panini was so bad I was tempted to throw it away. 

My recommendation? Order a glass of wine or a cappuccino, bring your own food, dine al fresco and enjoy the view.
author: Nicole G.

description: nice place to stop and have some fine Italian wine and enjoy a sunny day in Union square. Alena was a sweetheart and they were helpful with selections
author: Bill W.

description:
During the holiday season, I always take groups of children from local shelters I volunteer at to see the Christmas Tree all lit up in Union Square. A few years ago, it became a tradition to take these adorable little tykes into Emporio Rulli for hot chocolate and cookies (hey, I don't have to put them to bed). The staff at ER  are always so incredibly gracious and kind to my sometimes snotty-nosed, sometimes socially awkward, but always loving and always adorable noisy band of merrymakers. 

We've been treated with such kindnesses as free cookies, refills on hot cocoa, and replacement cocoas and cookies when originals managed to slip through mittened hands. I know if the children I volunteer with were old enough to understand, they'd be incredibly grateful to the great people at ER. Because Christmas trees are soooo much better with hot chocolate and cookies. 

**The location can't be beat and the coffee is pretty great. Prices are a little high, but you pay a premium in Union Square anywhere you go. Indoor space is limited but the outdoor seating is the draw anyway. And as a pIus, there are the million and one pigeons outside for the children to feed, coo at, and chase about.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I base this review on walking past this place 2 days in a row, stopping in one day to ask what the deal-io is here, and then finally the next day eating here.  The lure of sitting by the ice skating rink at Xmas time was too much to bear.  Had to.

+1 Star - Location location location.  Near the shopping (I can see Neiman Marcus, Louis V and Levi's all from my seat), near my hotel (and lots of hotels), near the ice rink.  Nuff said.
+ 1 Star - Outiside tables.  Glorious weather, especially in a place than can have other than that, makes one want to sit outside. Nothing more luxe feeling than having a meal outside in December when you know 1/2 the country is in snow.
- 1 Star - Food.  It's just not good.  It's not inedible, but it is sort of like good cafeteria food.  We had the lasagna (microwaved to heat up), a fruit salad (not bad at all, very fresh tasting, lots of different fruits), a ham&cheeze pannini (super unimpresssive) and cup of soup (minestrone that tasted from the can even if it were not.  That, and two bottles of water.
- 1 Star - Potty.  What? No potty?  Oh my.
+ 1 Star / - 1 Star - Help.  Nice counter folks, but a bit chaotic.
+1 Star - Vibe.  Reminds me of Europe.  Including the chaotic vibe.
- 1 Star - Price.  See above food.  Tab: 30-ish bucks (plus tip).  Seems a little steep for what you get.
+ 1 Star - Singing Homeless dude.  Some might be freaked out by it, but I liked the older gentleman who came around the tables and sang to people. He sang "You are so beautiful" at me, so I really liked it.  Be sure to tip!

All in all, though this place rather sucked on the edible front, it rather rocked on the three S's: Sights, Service and super convenient to where I am Staying so I am sure I will be here again.
author: Julia K.

description: I don't know if the fact that we sat outside and the weather happened to be perfect made me like this place even more, but I'm definitely a fan! I ordered the pear salad with grilled chicken and it was absolutely delicious. The restaurant was on a raised platform in the middle of Union Square so it was nice to be able to look all around me at all the beautiful buildings and shops. With Emporio Rulli being right in the center of everything, there was plenty of things to watch to keep myself entertained through lunch. The salad was so fresh and flavorful- I especially loved the tender chicken I had added to the salad. The waiter was attentive and friendly. He told us how delicious there coffee was but unfortunately we had just been to Starbucks so were not craving anymore. Next time I visit I will definitely have to grab a coffee and scone. Loved the atmosphere, great food also!!
author: Caroline F.

description:
Update 3/5/2007:  

I have finally found a time that I could actually patronize Emporio Rulli.  At 9:00 am on Monday, when the air was warm and clear and calm, I dropped in after a dentist's appointment.  A latte and a croissant cost me about $5.50.  The latte was just right, and was served in a ceramic cup.  The croissant, at first, appeared to be an ordinary American bakery croissant, but upon tasting it I found a hint of orange in the flavor.  The Italian music, while seemingly a bit obnoxious when heard on the Square, actually felt appropriate inside the cafe.  Today tables lined the cafe windows, so there was plenty of seating both inside and outside.  

I had a pleasant time relaxing before I went onward to my business day.  It was actually fun to watch the line grow, from a detached point of view.  If you want to read the frustration of  navigating the large line, read on.  

---------------
Original review:  

I have dropped by three times, now.  Twice at lunch, when the air was warm and the sky sunny, and once tonight, when the air was cold and dark.  All three times there was a long line and slow service, and tonight I noticed there were only two tables inside.  I've never stood in line long enough to order.  I give up.
author: David D.

description:
Location: 5 stars, primo for the times there are SF Jazz concerts.

Service: Minus 4 stars, there are more ratpigeons walking round the tables than ER staffers...

Quality of espresso: Mezzomezzo

Quality of pastry: looks like weekold leftovers brought via BART from the SF International Airport.

So I got the espresso at the counter and preceeded to attempt to find a seat at a table. Can I share this table with you? 
BBW: "NO, I am waiting for my friends!!!!!!!!"...
Me: thinking..."Damn witch, you don't even order anything and you holding 6 chairs here by yoself? You mus be waitin for yo hommies to be bringin da burrodown to get yo chaluppa on"

Find another table to share with someone else. The tables haven't been bused, so just clear the dirties and enjoy the sun...all 30 minutes of free Vitamin Ds worth.

LaCosanostraBambinos do not see repeat business.
author: miriam b.

description:
This place has it easy.. OK make your items a little pricey .. keep the place reasonably pleasant.. OK.. the pigeons are a problem.. just make sure to clean up after them.. make sure they don't flock on the patio tables.. but *who* is gonna say that having this pleasant place to sit and sip your beer, wine, or coffee on Union Square is a *bad* thing? We seem to end up sitting here for a half-hour or 45 minutes or so every time we're in the downtown section of SF..

As our real estate agent friends like to say.. location, location, location..
author: Weide Z.

description: A friend and I ventured into Union Square for a quick lunch. Working in downtown San Francisco, I'm used to $8+ sandwiches, so this place didn't phase me. I ordered the Milanese panini which is prosciutto crudo (cured ham) asiago cheese, fresh spring mixed greens and olive oil on a house-made focaccia. The sandwich itself was really good, the whole bite I got. It was the smallest sandwich I've ever seen (that wasn't a finger sandwich on some sampler platter). I was done a few bites and I was starving. Safe to say, I'm never going back to a place where I spend $10 for lunch and am left hungry.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Price for coffee wasn't too expensive, it was average - and on a nice day in SF, walking around Union Square with a cup of coffee makes me happy that I live here.  The coffee wasn't great, it was a little weak, but thankfully it was fresh.

But the iced tea, oh the iced tea!!!

My friend had one, and it smelled so phenomenal, I couldn't resist taking a sip.  Mind you, I'm a tea snob - I love my tea.  And their tea smelled so good!

The iced tea was as good as it smelled, and the generous slices of lemons they put in provided the right tang. 

Their pastries looked pretty good - can't wait to give it another try next time.

Best thing to do is probably just grab a coffee and a pastry and then soak up the nice, warm sunlight in Union Square.
author: Mary M.

description:
Ah, I found out what it's called... I just called it that cafe on Union Square! 
I was here once on a coffee date :) We sat outside, it was a sunny afternoon. It's obviously a popular spot for everybody because of the prime location. There were children about too. My date went inside to get our drinks and brought it out. I don't recall there were seatings inside. I had a hazelnut latte which was very creamy and smooth, nice. I wish they give you a glass of water like the Cafe in Paris do. I wish they have a toilette. I asked but I were told I had to go down to the parking lot.... we ended up stopping by Macy's for this! 

I will be back.
author: Bella A.

description:
Totally irritating. What self-respecting cafe refuses to serve a cappuccino breve (made with half and half)?! The woman working there said that yes, even though they have half and half, as evidenced by the quart of it sitting on the counter, they could not make me a cappuccino with it b/c they only make them in the traditional Italian way--with nonfat or regular milk. I *almost* started in on a diatribe about how I lived in Milan for a freakin year and didn't come across nonfat milk at all, and that what they used there most often was the scary, unrefrigerated milk that tasted slightly like baby formula. I didn't see them serving the unpasteurized stuff at Emporio Rulli, so they can bite me about their commitment to authenticity. 

And a third-party gripe. My friend ordered the almond croissant that didn't even look right--yellowish and small. She was starving so she ate it, but said besides the almond sliver on the top of the thing, the contents had never even rubbed shoulders with almond paste or the like. And it was $3, by the way. 

I'd always walked past this touristy-looking cafe, wondered if it was any good, and decided to wait til I could find a Peet's to get my coffee fix. Now I remember what my momma always tells me, "trust your instincts"!!
author: Gretchen T.

description: Glorious start to a Saturday morning. Enjoy a cup of coffee and breakfast panini and watch the city awaken as Union Square becomes alive with whatever local event is happening.
author: Marti H.

description:
I stopped by Emporio Rulli for the first time the other day and I was disappointed.  I had high hopes because of its location and its wares (well, it's actually food and drinks, but you get the point).  I have to agree with most of the people who have complained about their service, or lack thereof.  

I walked in, wanting a hot drink, and noticed that the line was long.  I attributed it to the fact that it was the tail end of lunch and they were finishing up with the lunch rush, but no...  That wasn't it.  When I finally made it to the register, I realized why the line was so long.  Service was impeccably slow, slow as molasses because it was so difficult to communicate with the cashier.  When it was my turn to order I politely said, "May I please have the Chocolate Del Doge and the chocolate cake with a raspberry on top?"  This started the round of "What drink? Hot chocolate?  What kind?"  I ordered what was being advertised on their counter.  Apparently, it's called Venetian hot cocoa, but that's not what the sign said!  She didn't get the cake right either.  

I kept my cool, paid for my drink and cake, walked out and thought "I'm not sure I want to come back here unless this stuff is really good."

Let me tell you about the "Venetian Chocolate."  It was super rich and sweet.  It was so syrupy that they had to serve it in a small cup.  They filled the cup (6 oz) half way with the hot chocolate then doused it with fresh whipped cream.  There was nothing spectacular about the drink.  It took me a while to get to the hot chocolate and it was hard not to get any whipped cream on my nose because the chocolate was super thick.  I've had European hot chocolate before and I know what to expect.  This wasn't it.

The cake was layered with chocolate mousse, regular cake, and fresh raspberries.  The mousse was delicious, but the cake itself was too dry.  The slice wasn't work the $4.50.

The place isn't the worst cafe I've visited, but I'll only stop by if someone else asks me to meet them there, or someone wants to check it out.  I don't have the urge to give them another try.  If I change my mind after another visit, I'll let you know.
author: Annalynn C.

description:
The place is at an incredible location; they are the one and only cafe on Union Square... and this is probably the reason why they still have any business. If they had the smallest competition they would be so closed!

The waiters that ignore you, the papers on the floor, and the dirty tables are not inviting, whatsoever. What particularly amazes me is the "Hyper-specialization": if you happen to order, as we did, a salad, a tea, and a pastry; they may come to you at three different times because apparently one person takes care of the food, another one brews the teas and who knows who's in charge at the "pastry department" (one of us had to go inside to eventually get it!) 

The long lines inside are just a turn off, and the staff is too rude to be true. Surprisingly, and for the first time, yesterday I saw a waiter taking someone's order (yes, he physically went to the table, menus on his hand, and in a few minutes took note of the requested food and drinks) and I wondered: Are they paying more that I am? Are they really that much cuter? Is their accent funnier than mine?

Yes, sitting outside, having a nice coffee while reading the paper and/or watching people go by is certainly very pleasant; but the dirtiness, the rudeness, the messiness, and the insufficient and inept waiting staff simply makes the whole enchantment vanish. Too bad.
author: Rosa L.

description:
When the sun is still out it's so nice to snag an outside table and enjoy a nice glass of pinot grigio.. they let you take your time here and don't try to hurry you out.

Great spot for a simple merienda...
author: Nenette Y.

description: Over all this place deserve a 5 stars. This location is perfect for people watching, nice little outdoor table to sit and relax in the sun. Very European feel to it. Since i can't really drink coffee, i order Gelati with two different flavors. I had hazelnut and coffee, funny that i can't drink it but i can eat it. It was great! I will try something else next time when i stop by for a visit.
author: Kayla D.

description: The chocolate brioche pastry is a let-down (See my photo)
author: Scott F.

description:
It's all about location, and this place has it.  Good variety for the food, excellent drinks, and being able to sit outside on a warm day in Union Square with a fine glass of wine or an Anchorsteam - well, it's just great!

Good for meeting people and friends, but there's not much value and a few too many vulturous pigeons here.
author: Jeff W.

description: My friend bought a bag of their coffee to bring home, it was that good. Nice spot in the middle of Union Square, too.
author: Celinda A.

description:
Came here on a Saturday morning for breakfast... The weather was perfect... The food yummy and the coffee amazing!! 

I had the turkey breast on foccacia with fontina cheese, spring greens and roasted red peppers. The bread was grilled and was super soft! The sandwich was simply delicious.

The coffee was some of the best that I've ever tasted. 

The service is pretty bad, but that's didn't change the fact that the food and coffee were tasty!
author: Jen D.

description:
On a lazy sunny day, and living in the neighborhood, we often will swing by here and have a panini and a bottle of wine. The food is decent, not great, but worth it. 
Just sitting and enjoying the hustle and bustle of downtown life, the tourists, the worker-bees and the shoppers while we sip our wine and watch the world go by. It makes me realize why I love living here, and what a great city it is.
author: Jason D.

description: The hot earl grey tea was good and it's a nice place to people watch but the young kid on the register gave me change for a $5 when I gave him s $20. He wouldn't even respond when I told him this, just looked away and went to the next customer, completely ignoring me. It's a shame as the teas and pastries are good and it's a nice place to hang out otherwise - just give them a credit card not cash!
author: Jacqueline B.

description:
"I am sitting at an outside table of Emporio Rulli. The rays of last sun are hitting the buildings. I smile to my plate of strawberries and blueberries, then take a sip from the frothy, hillariously expensive latte.  Life is beautiful. Through the speakers, an Italian tenor fills the air of the square. People are hovering over their tables, quiet conversation and relaxed poses ensure the elusion of a dreamy reality. The rush of the city is hushed here, magically guarded by the perimeter of the sidewalk. 

I put my coat on and walk across the plaza.  "-Excuse me!"  - I hear a voice.  I turn around and see a short dark-haired man with a friendly face. He looks very generic; he could be an office worker, a construction worker, or an telecommuting engineer.  "Hi!'  He takes a step back, looking for courage, then with a gulp of air, steps towards me, flustered.  "I just wanted to say..  I saw you sitting at the cafe.. " -he looks down.  "And, um, well, you are the very beautiful!"  I smile to myself.  I've heard this before.  Ah, yes, last time was in New York, Guggenheim Museum, lobby.  A tall blond, intense blue eyes. 

"Thank you", I say politely.  The man, encouraged, picks up the conversation:  "Are you a tourist?"  "Yes"-I lie. An eternal tourist, wondering through life. "Where are you from?"  "Austria"- I lie.  At least I wish I was. And then, an involuntary jolt of ecstasy runs through my heart and I almost say it outloud:  "And I'm meeting the man of my dreams in 5 minutes!" ...

For a moment, I'm in my thoughts, and then I am brought to reality by the friendly man.  "Well, welcome to America!" - he says with delight, speading his hands as if to give me all there is about his country. "
author: Anya B.

description:
walked over here to get some espresso and pastries two days in a row...
it was right up the street from the hotel we were staying at- just two blocks away and right in the union square. 
their espresso was smooth and rich and the almond brioche was nice and fluffy light. 
we sat outside in the square..... the views of the old St. Francis are a very lovely - along with the people sitting outside with their dogs.
there was a little bird that also came back to visit us 2 days in a row...
we called him stubby. he had a gimp foot and one tail feather...he was a brave little sparrow and would fly up to our hand to take the bits.
author: Noe'lle M.

description: A staple Italian 'bar'. Great cappuccino and pastries
author: B R.

description:
As a visitor here, it's hard not to be impressed with this place's location. I know it's right on Union Square and that probably makes it expensive, but I didn't care. I loved that I could walk 2 seconds out the door and enjoy my coffee in the sunshine and take in the people-watching. OK OK, I was partially in bliss because I was staying in the gorgeous St. Francis and it was no effort to get here, but still. Such a cute joint. 

Now, coming here to grab a drink is a different story. What's going on, do I sit outside, can I hold a table, is there table service, where does this line begin/end...chaos. We ended up leaving after waiting for 5 minutes because it was so all over the place. 

Still great for a coffee as a tourist though.
author: Purvi R.

description:
Great for people watching on the square and even better for their lattes.

I haven't tried any pastries, sandwiches, or any food for the matter - just lattes and americano's.  Emporio Rulli's is a bit pricey but I'd say it's probably worth it compared to Starbuck's.  

The latte's consistently come out delicious and always with foam on top.  The way a latte should be!
author: anita h.

description:
There is really no place for people watching like Union Square; Emporio Rulli provides the perfect vantage to sit and observe the traffic passing by.
The coffee was good, quite good in fact, and the barristas were friendly. My cappuccino had just the right amount of froth, and the right flavor. Sure it wasn't cheap in relation to the quantity, but the best things in life never are. The scone also stood out. Not too sweet, or cake-like, it struck the perfect balance between biscuit and cookie. Much better than the junk they call scones at $tarbucks. I'll go back any time
author: Dana L.

description:
2007-12-27

Maybe I've had better espresso since Rulli, or maybe their espresso wasn't as good as I remembered.  At any rate, it was a bit too diluted and tasted burnt bitter.  In other words, it tasted like any other espresso from any given espresso-serving coffee shop.  Oh well...

****
Delicious espresso!  Double for here, please!  Try the Milanese for a light lunch, and look through their dessert selections before falling in line.  It can get really busy here, but I do take in consideration where it is, so I avoid stopping by on weekends.  Hell, I avoid Union Square on weekends and during the Holidays, or at least I try to, but it's hard to pass by the square without having myself a shot or two.
author: Erick ..

description:
This place is one of the reasons I really love San Francisco.  

The best cappuccino in union square, awesome pastry/wine selection and the best people watching on a rare sunny day.  

I have to disagree with the people knocking the service.  I come here 3 times a week (at least) and the service is impeccable.  Servers (though sometimes few in number) are always helpful, often aid with the necessary swatting of aggressive pigeons, and don't mind if you loiter with your latte for an hour or two - no matter how busy the place is.  They also always put up with my constant switching of tables to score a better view...
author: D S.

description:
I like many Rulli locations, but definitely not this one!

The only thing I really like about this Union Square cafe is the chance to sit outside on a warm day and people watch.

I tried to do that today, and I realized, it just doesn't cut it when you throw away $7 for a tiny orange juice and a pastry that's too dry.

Inside the cafe, I always find that the floor and tables are dirty.

I'm pretty easy to please, but this overpriced Rulli should at least be a bit nicer inside and deliver in terms of quality.
author: Sophie D.

description:
I went to Emporio Rulli for dinner with my friend. The salad I got cost $9.71 and it didn't taste fresh. It tasted as if they put stall walnuts and canned pears on some lettuce and made me pay $10...I think that is a RIP OFF!!!

 I was expecting an amazing salad for that price (I am a college student, so that is a lot of money). 

Positive: The location is very nice because you get to sit on a patio and look out to see all of Union Square. If you go at night, it is very pretty if the weather has not much fog. 

If I were to go back here, I would get a hot cocoa and people watch because it is a GREAT location but my dinner was not good at all..... 
But my friend got a sandwitch and enjoyed it very much. They also have a full bar which if I was 21 that might be cool! lol
author: LB D.

description: Consistently disappointing.  I keep going back because I work near Union Square and on the rare warm sunny days, it is hard to resist the outdoor seating in the square.  But the food is really ordinary.  Caesar salad is soppy wet, cheese plate is sparse, and panini sandwiches are dry and tasteless.  They cater mainly to the tourist set, so seems like they feel like their business model is all about curb appeal and not food quality.  For a better outdoor meal in the area, go down Maiden Lane accross the street (Stockton) and enjoy the offerings at Mocca, which is 50% more expensive than Emporio Rulli, but 200% better!
author: David K.

description:
So I have been here a few times now, mainly for brunch and most recently for dinner.  While the food was delicous, I mean the freshest bread that I have ever been served.  The salad was so simple, and fresh and then my entree had artistic quality to it...But the service annoyed me.  Neither of us were exactly starving and it was fairly late so I wasn't up for a big meal, but our server insisted that it would be 13 minutes for the one dish to be prepared so we should order a starter.  It actually took double the time for the meals to come out.  Then the server needed to be reminded to bring another glass of wine...I don't know.  He just got under my skin for some reason....besides the ones I listed.

Also, the decor is very romantic with some of the most beautiful hand painted murals..I have tasted some of the bakery items, and I think they are very tasty.
author: Amy Z.

description: Perfect coffee and hangout place in Union square. The cappuccino was  the best compared to all of the places I have previously had it in the US. Great joint.
author: Gopi V.

description: Pretty standard coffee joint if you ask me. 3-star for the most part, except they've got a slightly more extensive menu and a great location - right in Union Square Park!
author: Brad Y.

description: Some locations are just too conspicuous to be able to have high expectations at, and a cafe *inside* Union Square is certainly one of those (the fact that it was imported from the Marina didn't get my hopes up either).  So it was no surprise that the lattes, paninis and tiramisu don't scream out for love like those at, say, Mario's.  But if you're coming for people-watching, particularly on a brisk (actually we had to settle for balmy) December day when the tree and ice rink are up and the shoppers rush by with their [anti-consumerism rant redacted] treasures, you just might enjoy lunch at one of the patio tables here, and you can even get (polite, if harried) table service.  So bonus star for being an example to other tourist-swarmed eateries on how to mitigate the inevitable mediocrity.
author: Wes M.

description: Absolutely fantastic coffee and desserts. Great location to hang out and relax after or before shopping.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Nice little spot to stop by for some coffee and a snack. Very european style cafe - pastries, sandwiches, salads, soup and even wine.  Went here on Valentine's Day after a nice walk downtown.  Two soy lattes and a cinnamon twist came out to about $12.50.  Definitely not Starbucks prices.  It was raining off and on, but we sat outside under an umbrella.  Nothing like some hot drinks in the cold weather. Romantic almost. Sort of like being at a cafe in Paris or Italy. Not that I would know, but I watch the Travel Channel and Food Network enough to imagine. 

The girl who took our order was kind of weird though. I nicknamed her "crazy eyes" because she stared at my partner with her eyes all wide after he placed his order. I was like.. girl why you looking at him all crazy?"  The barista made a great soy latte complete with a cute little heart design in the foam. 

Unfortunately, the canella (cinnamon twist) was dry and bordering stale. It looked scrumptious behind the glass. I think it was the lighting.
author: Joshua C.

description:
The espresso is good and the pastries are grand. Honestly, I didn't expect good coffee coming from such a tourist trap area. So I come here when I can and grab a cup of coffee and a pastry (either a plain brioche, an apple turnover, or anything that takes my fancy) and sit outside and tourist watch. 

If I can, I'll sit in one of the small tables provided by Emporio Rulli, but I warn you NOT to feed any bird. Don't feed the cute little birdies or the pretty exotic feathered friends. But most of all, DO NOT, I repeat DO NOT FEED THE PIGEONS!! I've seen this done by many a tourist and when bird word goes around that someone's giving out food, then all creatures born with feathers (most are from the leather vested, chain tot'n pigeon gangs) descend on the hapless tourist(s). What is one to do? but to say, "Poor schmuck" and turn away . . .

As for the cafe's service, it's okay. I have to remember that these servers deal with tourist all day long and it's the tourist that take up most of the time. How can you wait in a long line and NOT know what the fuck you what?? Jeez.
author: Audrey S.

description:
It was a beautiful Sunday morning at Union Square.
We got an outdoor table, and I got this pretty Spinach Panini, yet our drink didn't arrive with food.

The waiter who dropped off my food and picked up the number plate said that we were supposed to pick up our drinks inside, so we went inside.

"What is your number?"
'Number? I don't know.'
"What's your name? Are you Pam?"
'No I am not Pam.'
"Oh I made your latte like 10 minutes ago. I will make one now for you. "
'Okidoki.'

...and when we returned to the table with drinks...
Pigeons having a feast on our table!!

My breakfast was theirs.
It was a very scary scene.

I gave up, took a picture of the birds and sat down at two table down. 

At least I had latte that birds never have tasted in their life.

However, a manager-like man in black bow tie, vest and pants at the cafe came to say "We'll bring you another. But don't leave the table this time. Okay?" 

Yes, they gave me new one quickly, and it was fluff, warm and delicious. 

I wondered if the birds had tasted and knew that was so good. Anyway I was feeling much better, rather heavenly under the sun with warm food and funny incident.

Sure this place is touristic, and does a good job in that way.
author: Chacha M.

description:
THE PLACE:
it's a smallish coffee shop, it's pretty anonymous feeling. Usually you'll sit outside because there are a lot more seats out there.

THE FOOD:
I've never had coffee here but their pastries aren't that good. 

Their location is pretty hard to beat if you're in union square though.
author: Michael S.

description:
The perfect respite when you need it. Emporio Rulli may not be perfect, but when you've been shopping too long and you desperately need a pick-me-up, it's perfect. 

A latte, a mocha and a panini-pressed verde foccacia gave us the boost we needed to attack the Macy's dress department (and ran just over $10). All were well-prepared and easy enough to pick up from the counter. I can see how it could be complicated to pick up drinks, then food, but we'd nabbed a table inside and it was hassle-free. 

Mostly, it's times like this---having a good cup of coffee with a cute boy and watching the tourists go by---that remind me why I love San Francisco. I always get nostalgic when I see tourists; the fact that so many people travel so far to see this place makes me feel special to live here.
author: Erin M.

description:
I love outdoor seating. I love coffee. I love interesting architecture. Mini Rulli totally checks off the list. If they weren't so slow and disorganized behind the counter, I'd give them five stars. The fact that it took three people to ring up, pour and serve me a small black coffee is a little inefficient. 

Hang ups aside, this is an awesome spot to grab a soda or coffee and sit and watch the world go by. Just watch out for the pigeons.
author: Zac H.

description:
I want to love this place: it's right on Union Square, outside seating in the warm sun w/a cool breeze, people watching, fresh food from Marin, physically appealing pastries... but.... honestly Rulli, can we just be friends?

It's priced ok, i supposed, 6.95 for panini... but even though the portions are good, they just don't look appealing! In the Bay Area, we are spoiled... not only with good quality food, but with great presentation even in average cafes. So when the only cafe on the square gives bland looking sandwiches (I know it's panini, but it doesn't look like it!), the meal is already disappointing. 
AND the freakin crazy birds have NO SHAME... they will land on your table w/their huge pointy beaks and poke at your food!!!! 

So even tho my and my friend's paninis were edible and the chocolate/cream/berry cake we got wasn't too bad.... i won't be going back here... or maybe i'll give it another shot w/a big mug of cappuccino
author: Sofia J.

description: Great place to enjoy an afternoon coffee and watch the world go by.
author: Andy M.

description:
You are going to want to biotch-slap the people who get to the front of the line and then start asking technical questions about the pastries.  Ma'am, if you don't recognize that's an apricot, you are not going to like it. Get a croissant and a clue.  I love the location, love the coffee, love the drinks and wine, but they need to rethink the service process.  They also need to be more aggressive about shooing away the big clots of stupid high school kids ganging up on the tables without eating or drinking anything from the cafe.  Take the makeout party somewhere else, kids.

Oh, one last thing.  BUS those freaking tables!
author: Kevin S.

description:
Their cafe au lait is the best i've had so far =] it's nice and creamy.. and maybe because i put the right amount of sugar into the cup this time =P

Well the times i've been there before.. they're kinda slow.. as in processing what i want.. and another time they didn't give me the right change.. but i don't blame them i do that sometimes when i'm overworked =/ 

Fruit salad's not worth the 5 bucks but i guess anywhere that serves fruit salad around union square would be that price.. the fruit salad here didn't look fresh although the grapes were VERY sweet =] the watermelon looked icky maybe it was the season. 

Iced Tea.. it was good =] i think the palace hotel uses the same tea (don't quote me).. it has that distinct scent.. couldn't place my finger on it 

Well if you want an outdoor cafe you get the entire package.. pigeons and people included.. i wish the pigeons would just leave us alone and make us less paranoid about being the 1 in a million to get bird crap on their head

Their pastries look like something you'd find in a high school ceramic class.. the flaky pastries are all glazed
author: Connie M.

description:
Good quality espresso, although I've had better in non-Italian joints in this city... which is both sad and shameful. That's not to say Rulli's is bad. It's not. It's just that Ritual Roasters and Blue Bottle do it better somehow.

Good toasted panini. Not spectacular, but they make for a satisfying lunch.

They occasionally have budini di riso (Italian rice custard pastries). That immediately puts them in the favorable column. Other desserts have been so-so.

The service is pretty crappy. I guess that's what happens when you pump tourists through a place all day long.
author: Angelo B.

description:
I love this cafe because of its location and their coffee has enough "umph" in it to get me through shopping downtown. I love getting the iced caffe latte. It is the perfect blend of coffee and milk over ice. No sugar for me thanks! 

Also, got their chocolate brioche which was flaky and not too sweet. The dusting of dark cocoa powder on top is a bit deceiving. At first I thought, oh crap, its burned! Hahahah!

Love the ambiance of this quasi-European bistro in Union Square.
author: Maritel C.

description: I only had a hot chocolate but it was soooo good! The environment is adorable and has such a foreign and unique feel to it, not to mention it's location is perfect. The baristas were a little snobby but still a cute place.
author: madina a.

description:
I have a love hate relationship with Rulli.  I love it's location and it's my favorite cup of coffee in the city.   I love that you can go order a bottle of wine and sit outside and people watch.  I love the music they play, the ambiance is very romantic.  (Though watch out for the pigeons!) 

However I agree entirely with Shane A's review on the service.  I am not sure if the staff are rude or if they just don't have the mental skills to ring up a cup of coffee in less than 10 minutes and in the 4 years I have been coming here I think if it's possible, the service has gotten even slower!
author: Jenny R.

description: Yum.  Visited the Larkspur store and Union Square. I recently organized a skating show "A Celebration of Bay Area Skating" to celebrate the successes of the competitive skaters this season. Lauren and Randy from Rulli were kind enough to donate hot cocoa and awesome good cookies. It was a cold night and thanks to Rulli the skaters were warm and cozy and well fed. Thank you Rulli!!!
author: Susan B.

description: I didn't order anything here, but my friend did and we relaxed outside in the Square under an umbrella table.  The people at the table next to us left, and all of a sudden, swarms of pigeons flew from all directions to scavenge the leftovers (see photo).  It was pretty disgusting and frightening.  But my friend enjoyed his pastry and milk.
author: Nunya N.

description:
If it wasn't for the fact that this caf is located in one of the best locations in San Francisco I probably would never go there. It is a great place to people watch and they have a lot of outdoor seating;  which is sometimes hard to find. However, I do have to agree with some of the other Yelpers that the service is lacking and you typically have to fight for an outside table. 
I as many other people are lactose intolerant and must half soy milk with my coffee. When I asked if I could have soy mocha, I was told that "they were an Italian coffee shop and therefore did not carry soy milk." Excuse me! I primarily go to Italian coffee shops and have never been denied my Soy milk before. Needless to say I walked up the street to Caf Espresso (an Italian coffee shop that serves Illy coffee) and had no trouble ordering my soy mocha
author: Angela P.

description:
So much to love about this cafe but so much to be disappointed in too.

The espresso is terrific, IF made well...If they could only combine the techniques of Blue Bottle with the roast they use here they'd have an awesome espresso.

Pastries are reaaally the worst here which is unfortunate as their Larkspur location is much better...Perhaps it's the volume they do or that they simply allow for pastries to stack up and become quite old/stale but the quality is substandard...Amazed whenever I see people continue to purchase pastries there...Just goes to show you, people will eat just about anything.

The location is great and perfect when it's a sunny day in SF.

Unfortunately, lines do accumulate here as it's a popular tourist spot but if I'm in the area, I won't go anywhere else for a macchiato
author: Barca F.

description: I love this little spot. It's perfect for sunny day shopping in Union Square. The outdoor tables are packed, but if you are patient and take the time to look, you'll definitely be able to find a spot. We decided an afternoon brew on one of the only sunny days we've had in awhile sounded amazing. I was assigned table duty and found a great spot right outside the front doors. He got us two beers and a delicious ham and brie sandwich, omg yes please. The brie was perfectly creamy, and the whole sandwich had amazing flavor. Of course we decided to order a second beer, because that weather was much to nice to pass up! The only downfall was that their bathroom was across the way and down the stairs in their garage, so if you know you will need to go you should plan in advance. All of their other food looked really good- like their salads and olive plates, and of course their pastries. Their pitcher of sangria also looked like a great idea, which I will definitely be back for with friends on my next sunny day shopping trip!
author: Sonya D.

description:
The sandwich I had contained a thin layer of really crappy, overly fatty procuittio that I wouldn't even feed to my cat, some parmesan of questionable quality, and wilted greens. Who the hell puts greens in a sandwich that gets grilled? Who wants nasty soggy greens? Oh, and the bread -- their "house-baked focaccia" -- is garbage, too thin and doughy, flavorless.

The only upside was the bottle of bubbly water (which was NOT twist off, and was not opened for me; I had to go back to the counter and ask two different employees). The water washed the taste out of my mouth and helped erase that poor excuse of a lunch from my palette.

Too bad. The location is great.
author: Max S.

description:
I concur with other reviewers; good food and coffee (though my pastry was hideously stale today).

But that is no conciliation for ugly, throw-away cups; unbussed tables everywhere; a line that would disappear with a coffee cart out front (why should I have to explain this to people?); in general, a place that takes advantage of its perfect location.  

They don't have to try harder, so they don't.

Voila.
author: Antoine de S.

description:
If I was only to write about the service, I would give this place a -5. The staff could care less about any of their guests. And to top it all off, it took almost 30 minutes to get a prosciutto and brie sandwich. I should have just accepted my loss and walked out. I say lose the attitude, it doesn't make you look pretty. Even the Europeans in the place were appalled by their display of superiority. 

However, the sandwich was tasty, but small. The pastries looked divine and I will go back (to be treated like crap) and try some of their deserts. Maybe they will have cannoli that day. Or maybe I'll just venture to North Beach if I want Italian deserts.
author: Shane A.

description: My fiance and I have been here 3 times since we discovered it last week.  Funny thing is that we live downtown SF and we always walk through union square but we never bothered to stop at this place.  Wish we would've stopped by here long time ago!  The weather has been beautiful lately so we've been soaking up the sun and dining outside.  We've had their iced coffee and mocha drinks, peroni on tap, several of their paninis, pastries, desserts, and salads.  They all have been quite good.  I think the weather and being outside on union square made everything taste even better.  It definitely is very touristy but i get a kick out of seeing people come to SF from around the world for vacation and I'm lucky enough to LIVE here!
author: Jojo L.

description:
oh, emporio rulli, what is to be done with you?  i want to give you five stars, but i just cannot.

your location is magnificent - few things in this city could possibly be more entertaining than sitting outside and scanning the strange examples of humanity that stride accross union square.

your drinks are delightful - well-prepared and consistently tasty.  as well as a fine cup of coffee, you even provide decent black tea.  a boon among so many bad cupfuls of tea and coffee to be had accross this city.

your pastries are stellar - the croissants are soft AND flaky without leaving your tongue coated in a layer of grease.  i highly recommend both the almond and chocolate ones.

all these fine attributes.  so why, then, does your staff have to consist of a BUNCH OF FUCKING ASSHOLES.  it doesn't matter how polite i am ("may i" and "please" are always a part of my usually uncomplicated order of breakfast tea in a small cup to go).  it doesn't matter that i tip at least a dollar EVERY SINGLE TIME i purchase above-mentioned cup of tea.  this is the only place i have ever visited where i have actually had my change SHOVED into my hand with a sneer.  after i smiled and said "may i" and "please" and patiently waited as the person behind the counter forgot to give me my substantial amount of change and then took over 90 seconds to pry open the drawer and procure it.

it's actually to the point that i dread having to go in to order anything.  i feel fear.  i do not want to be abused (or do i?  see what this place does!).  but i want that tasty beverage, and i want to bask in the sun and watch bad outfits strut by on union square badly enough that i keep going back, despite the abuse, questionable haircuts, and line that i will find inside.  but maybe, if i'm just nice enough, finally one day, emporio rulli will tell me that it loves me.

in other words, emporio rulli is like the stokholm syndrome, only with a killer view...
author: genevieve g.

description: I love the location of this cafe. It is the perfect place to sit outside with friends and people-watch over coffee and a brioche. The coffee and pastries here are also quite good.
author: Alexander S.

description: I love this place. It is ideal for meeting people who are not really familiar with San Francisco because anyone can find Union Square! They could do better with more tables and a more organized management of the patrons sitting at them but it works. The coffee is excellent and the pastries and snacks are pretty good, too. On a sunny day there is no better place to have a beer or a glass of wine and people watch. You'll feel transported to Europe without leaving the City!
author: Kevin E.

description: Fine cup of coffee.  Grab a cup and something sweet to cap an afternoon of downtown shopping...if there are no tables, get it to go and take a seat somewhere else on the square where you can gawk at gawking tourists who are giddy with the glamour of our downtown shops.
author: L W.

description: I have to agree with the folks who awarded the Emporio Rulli with five stars. Union Square is a thoroughly beautiful place and the coffeeshop which is Emporio complements it perfectly. The pastries are wonderful and I've never been disappointed by their brews. One time I ordered an iced coffee on a hot day, and the barrista kind of surprised me by saying, "Here ya go, bella," in a really snide tone. It sounded like a sarcastic insult - that's how I could have taken it. But after I added some sugar, stirred it up, and began strolling the square (whilst sipping coffee) I realized that it was exactly what I had a taste for. Emporio Rulli could be pretentious, but it's not. It's just exemplary.
author: Evelyn B.

description: Even if they didn't have Venecian hot chocolate (YUM!), the huz and I would give this place 5 stars for the people who work there. Tonight, the huz took out a roll of cash to leave a tip, and then put the roll down on the counter while he put the lid on the chocolate. You guessed it -- he left the roll on the counter. An hour later, I called to ask if they had found it not expecting that they had (huz was so sure he wouldn't even call). Yet, they'd found it and held it for us. We'll be going to this place long after hot chocolate weather is over -- just so we can leave big fat tips! THANK YOU!
author: Cydney B.

description:
ew. 

mold on my pasta salad. 

and the french manager who i complained to was le-poo!

oh and ps, the woman, brigita, who took my order snickered at me because i didnt know how to pronounce "glace" as in cafe glace.
author: terra d.

description: Four stars for what it is -- counter service coffee and pastry bar. They do have sandwiches, but you're in Union Square and I think you could be more resourceful than to eat here. One thing, the coffee is outstanding. I drink dry cappuccinos and it is rare you can get one done properly. The people watching is great. All the folks complaining about service should maybe try a restaurant where that's provided.
author: Robert M.

description: I always liked the tarts and coffee here. Additionally, I love the location (obviously). In general, its a nice place to refuel after a day of shopping or a nice place to get some caffeine inside in order to prepare for one.
author: Andrew W.

description: Great coffee, great people watching, and good pastries (as long as it's before noon). The service here can be slooooow if you're getting an espresso drink and you're lucky if they get your order correct BUT the location makes it almost okay. I hate those damned pigeons outside but that may just be a personal problem I have with flying rats.
author: Jane K.

description:
can't believe i've managed to NOT review emporio rulli...

on a warm san franciscan day, this place is just delightful.  yes, there are some pretentious patrons, yes, it getsextremely  crowded, but somehow it is all worth it to me when i have my brie sandwich in hand, and am sitting in the sun!

wonderful and beautiful place for a bite!
author: Jill k.

description: I love the coffee at this place. Rulli is located right in Union Square and it has a great selection of Italian pastries.  They serve a great cappuccino. Head to this place before the stores open so you'll be able to enjoy Union Square without the crowds of people.  This is a favorite spot for me.
author: Veronica V.

description: Exceptional iced tea. Smooth and barely sweet like a Guinness in Cork. It's a small compensation to forgive the paving job they did to this once-lush (and slightly scary) park.
author: Brandon R.

description: I luuuuuv the grilled eggplant, mozzarella, red pepper sandwich (the "favorito").  Sitting at a table outside, watching people from all over the world while reviewing work in the sun over lunch and in between the endless droning hours of endless talking and questions and trying to pay attention and stay sharp on the same subject after same subject just mixed up and back again, is nice, more than nice, yep.  Love the little tiny pastries like mini creme puffs, mini tarts, little cute sugary creamy chocolatey pillows. Yum.
author: Today Y.

description: J says: Granted the latte was pretty good, but $6.50 for a single latte and a teeny chocolate budino seems a bit much, especially when the budino tasted stale!!  Blech...
author: Jen Ken H.

description: What really makes this place so great is the setting!  The coffee is just ok, the sweets also nothing special, but getting a table outside, in Union Square on a sunny day, life changing!  It feels like a little piece of Europe in the center of this modern city.  I really cannot think of a more ideal way to spend my afternoon other than sitting outside, drinking coffee from a mug and smoking, it's wonderful!
author: Steven K.

description:
v. v. crowded, + you often have to wait in long, long, long lines HOWEVER, it's worth the wait, try the
chocolate-pear tart ( trust me on this one, i know it sounds blech but...)
pistachio cannoli ( little tiny flakes of pistachio, mmmmmm)
fruit tarts ( tiny, cheerfully colored)
author: Holly Golighty M.

description: I knew I shouldn't have expected any more than I got at a place in the middle of Union Square.  Very mediocre panini's and rude service.  Few things annoy me more than when you order something off the menu and the counterperson looks at you like you are from Mars for thinking that they have that item.  Wife and I ordered a Lemon and an Almond italian soda off the menu.  She looks at me like we're crazy and says they don' t have those, then points to a shelf 30 feet away on which are randomly stacked bottles of syrup.  They have those ones.  So we get two other flavors and they both are poor also.
author: Patrick W.

description: A great pit stop during a shopping marathon on the Square. Equidistant between Banana flagship and Nordstrom, so this gets lots of traffic when Amanda and I are shopping it up. The location on Chestnut has turned into a full service diner and is much better on the food side than this location.
author: Todd J.

description: So Euro, but with boring pastries. Great coffee though. It's so nice to hang out in Union Square on a sunny day or for a shopping break. I hadn't been back since they remodeled it.
author: Thanya S.

description: Slow pokes.    Even though my iced coffee took twenty minutes to arrive, I"ll give three stars.  Maybe it was a slow day.  Or a busy day.  The coffee was great, but the wait was excruciating.  It took even longer to pay our check.
author: Amme P.

description: They got a great location and I love the design of the place. Right on in Union Square and on a nice sunny day in san francisco just great to sit and enjoy. Good selection of small eats and drinks. However, because of the location, they can charge higher which they do. But its worth it once and awhile and enjoy.
author: Leon C.

description: Great for people watching, reading, etc. since the locale couldn't be more central to union square.  Food is cafe style, pastries, salads, quiches, etc. but isn't anything special.
author: Jared F.

description: Emporio Rulli is a great place to get a glass a wine of the day, a nice smoked salmon panini or cup of  coffee and just chilled and hang out with a good friend on a SUNNY day.   But everything else is just okay and as most people pointed out. Skip the pastries.  Not at all impressive.
author: Chris C.

description: This is not my favorite Rulli's location. Larkspur and Chestnut Street are better. This location is phenomenal for a nice day, people watching... But my grilled panino was just so-so. I'll give them a break for now but I hope next time it's lots better!
author: Dana R.

description:
Ordered a vanilla latte -- they put more syrup in the drink than they did espresso or milk.  Was disgusting.  

Ordered a sandwich (which looked delicious sitting under the glass), but when the waiter brought me something completely different from what I'd ordered, I tried to get them to bring me the correct one.  That's when the manager came out and (instead of trying to fix the order), made a big show of telling me that I didn't know what I was talking about.  

Was surreal.  A great location, but not worth it.
author: Adam C.

description: I love coming here on a sunny day to watch tourists.  It's got a great Italian feel and also serves typical italian cafe fare. I always come here for my break from shopping. Problem is I just hate getting up and leaving.
author: Roger H.

description: Great snacks & wine. Good music. Sometimes it's hard to find/get a seat on the weekend. Service fluctuates between outstanding sometimes excellent other days and poor, but usually being in the first two catagories.
author: Ricardo O.

description: I fell in love with San Francisco while having breakfast here.  I sat at an outdoor patio on the Square observing the art sale and in ear shot of a beautiful European family taking in rapid swedish.  Needless to say, I go there quite often.  The ice tea and panini's are great too!
author: Robert K.

description:
I'm amazed that people seem so forgiving of an expensive, inept and semi-hostile cafe. Really now. If you were stuck in downtown.... if you felt compelled to people watch, if you are willing to have your order changed by the consistancy with which they are out of menu items, then maybe, just maybe, it would be worth the effort to go there.

Location pretty, good tea and coffee, nice pastry. 

Nevertheless, there are other pretty views and good tea in SF. Don't go unless you are stuck. Speaking of stuck... tables are frequently sticky and lord help you if you ask them to wipe them off.

Too expensive for the view. There are nice cafes over in N. Beach... or closer on Sutter. There are fantastic sandwich places over near Yerba Buena, with good cookies and everything. Do yourself a favor and take a miss on this one.
author: Kim S.

description: What's more indulgent than sipping champagne, nibbling on a decadent Italian pastry, basking in the San Francisco summer sun, while gossiping about the eye candy all around you. NOTHING! DO IT! It's buzzed, fatty, gossip girl shenanigan's at its best.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: I swear that this place makes the BEST cafe mocha.. Not too bitter , and taste chocolaty enough.. Other than that, they have tasty pastries and freshly squeezed orange juice..simply the best!
author: Iche S.

description: When the time you just wanna some coffee, with the 100% joyful smooth taste and a relaxing seat outdoor plus people watching, I came here. A bit pricey, some people say. I don't agree... 3.25 for small non fat latte, not bad at all. As usual, with the headset on, I ordered to go and then just sitting on the stairs the union square, between the rains and sunshine this noon. Not many people here, and I wasn't pay much attention to them anyway. Anyway, the staffs here are always smiling and very polite. The folks come here always nice and friendly. A homeless past me this time. He asked what I'm writing about(I was have my journal book opened in front of me.) And then he seemed just talk to himself that he was always trying to write something... and then, he wished me have a lovely day. Things like this always can make me smile. I guess this location is a big part of reasons that you will fall in love with this cafe just like I did. Feel the beats, the breath, the sunshine, the people and the city noise. One sip for yourself, one sip for a nice day and one sip for the life.
author: Flora F.

description: This coffee shop always seems to be busy, I'm sure the tourist to Union Square keep it that way. As a local, I've never been tempted to eat there. I would give this place a 5 star for LOCATION, but for everything else, a mere 2 star. Great place to sit and sip while people watching.
author: Hieu D.

description: I haven't had coffee this good since I was in Italy, not to sound like a tool, but seriously, it's excellent. There was a long line on the Saturday morning we were there, but it went by very efficiently. We bravely resisted the elaborate spread of pastries and took a table outside on a beautifully sunny SF day. My friend complained, but I think the nearby pigeons only added to the European feel.
author: Rachel B.

description: Fine, fine coffee at this place. The pastries...eh. If you can stand the long lines and rushed service (have your money ready), go for a table outside. Beware the pigeons. My last time there was marred by a bleeding pigeon that landed on our table. Blood dripped into my coffee upon its descent, which I lovingly passed onto my darling accomplice. But rejoining the line of locals and lemmings alike was worth a second cup.
author: Karen B.

description: Location location location. What a fantastic place to grab some good coffee during the heart of the holiday season. Sipping on your delicious drink, looking at the lights and tree in Union Square, how can you go wrong. The line was long for this popular shop but it was worth the wait and helped make a memorable evening. I got a plain and simple mocha coffee and it was good. I would have had a pastry but the selection was limited by the time we got there around 8 or 9pm. If I'm in town again I will not hesitate to grab some more java here.
author: Jason F.

description:
the best part of shopping are the breaks from shopping, and Emporio Rulli really helps extend those breaks luxuriously, and they get paid for that service, thankyouverymuch. The cappuccinos in my opinion are some of the best in city. I also find the panini--especially the Brie & prosciutto cotto, or the prosciutto with arugula and asiago--are really really yum and warming, each bite a little island of calm in the crowd. I haven't tried the pasrties because I don't go there for breakfast. 
The pigeons are a good distraction from all the people watching--during the day they swoop down on tables as soon as people vacate them, and re-enact choice scenes from the birds with Half-Eaten Croissant playing the part of Tippi Hedren. 
I appreciate that the staff take their time to make your coffee and grill your bread--more time away from shopping! YAY!
Plus, the creamy delicious cappuccinos, meant to be drunk from porcelain (not paper), hide a hidden gem I call caffiene.
author: Renu C.

description: I only order the non-fat cappuccino when I need a caffeine fix. The cappuccino is always good, however the service just sucks a$$. This place is quite crowded on the weekends and when its crowded, it takes 15 mins to get your espresso. Most of the staff comes off rude and snobby. However the espresso is good and the foam is the right consistency!
author: Amy W.

description: Rulli is great for it's central meeting grounds, good coffee and let's not forget the fabulous open space. SF needs more public space/ gather places. Esp, as we become a solo nation of ipods, pda's, laptops and cell phones we forgot how to interact and socialize with people face to face.
author: Tamz O.

description: Great warm drinks for a cool day, plus sandwiches and lots of different breakfast pastries.
author: Bee H.

description: I know it's a touristy area...but the lines are long and the service sucks with not even a small selection of patisseries.  I recommend going to the Marina
author: annie z.

description: This place is bad. You go inside and there is no menu on the wall, the pastries that they are supposed to be famous for do not have either name tags or prices. And they taste like 2 days old. If you sit inside, you feel like people ligning up near the counter are hovering above your table. If you sit outside, be prepared to allow pigeons to eat from your plate. The service...you know the feeling of frustration when you are in line and there is only one person at the counter...and the other two are just chatting instead of jumping in and helping out? Be prepared to experience that too. I know it is a touristy place, and people who actually live in San Francisco would never go there, but come on, you can do better than this.
author: Lena R.

description:
If you need somewhere quick that is outside and away from the bustling throngs without having to duck into a hotel restaurant or department store basement that's easy to find, go to Emporio Rulli Union Square.

The desserts, coffees, and wine bar are your best bet here. Great venue to enjoy Union Square especially, during the Holidays.  OK. OK. So, you may wait in line for awhile or your salad might be a little wilted. They only have so much room in the place to handle the huge volume of customers who keep coming back for more. I love the ambience and the feel of the place. That's why we all keep coming back.

You just have to know what to order, stop complaining and chill - can't  think of a cooler place to compare.
author: Rose M.

description: On a sunny day, believe it or not, this is one of the best cafe's in which to park yourself with a paper, a book, and a notepad. On a sunny day, wear sunglasses and look good. The espresso here is first class, as are the baked goods. You'd think it's all for tourists, but that's exactly what makes this such a find!
author: adrian c.

description:
The location, pastries and coffee are what make this place worth a visit.  The mob of tourists is a pain, but it's a nice place to stop off for a drink and a snack while shopping.  

I've ordered paninis twice, and both times, the edges of the bread have been very wet, even after the panini press.  It pretty much ruins the sandwich, no matter how tasty it may still be.  But, it's so convenient to grab something there.  

I also wish they would put up more umbrellas.  Granted SF isn't the warmest place on earth, but it still gets really sunny.  The metal tables also get VERY hot - you could cook an egg on them.  For the large number of tables, they need more than 4 or 5  umbrellas.
author: Claire P.

description:
finally someone has said it! this is a CAFE! NOT A RESTAURANT!!
What the hell is wrong with the majority of you people who have written reviews? 

A coffee shop isn't supposed to be like starbucks....good coffee is hand crafted, not just popped out...meaning you have to WAIT.

Yes, the line can be long, but do you think its due to the staff? PAY ATTENTION the next time you are there.  I watched the very patient cashier try to communicate with someone who had waited in line chatting with their friend for 10 minutes and never thinking they may need to decide what they wanted, and then they couldn't understand that drinks were called out by names----seriously?!  The staff is working fast and hard, its the people in line that are the issue (and they seem to be the same ones reviewing this place....color me surprised)

The staff is pleasant, the food good----if the city would enforce the no smoking law it would be a perfect place.
author: jane J.

description: i ordered a bellini, and you gave me a $9 glass of peach juice.  when i went to return it, i didn't expect a pigeon to have eaten my croissant.  service couldn't get worse, and if it wasn't in such a prime location, it wouldn't still be here today.  if you're gonna wait an hour for a pannini, you ought to at least have a seat to do so in.
author: Ariane R.

description: occasionally i'll stop by here on a warm sunday afternoon and i'll stand in a long long line to get an iced americano and if i'm feeling skinny maybe an oversized pastry. the 15 minutes wait time in line really doesn't bother me much as it gives me more time to stare and drool over all the decadent pastries and goodies in the display cases-- palmiers, eclairs, tarts, and brioches...salads and sandwiches...everything always looks so tempting but its one of those places where you go more for the location and atmosphere than for the fare. i suppose if i was in a hurry and it wasn't a warm sunday afternoon this caffe would lose much of it's appeal.
author: helen l.

description: I have been here a few times now. Everytime included a great cup of coffee and friendly employees! Speedy service, a huge selection of food (salads, sandwiches, pastries galore, which I haven't ventured into yet), outdoor seating which, is always kept clean. They are a bit pricey compared to other local coffee shops but its a nice spot to sit down and enjoy a great cup of coffee in the heart of union square.
author: morgan a.

description: The location is nice, it's right in the middle of union square
author: RO Z.

description:
If it weren't for the location, I would've been saying "Why won't Yelp let us give a place ZERO stars??" If you'll notice, the best reviews are all about the location. They're true. It's a beautiful locale. It's great to sit outside and see all the tourists and locals. But the food/drink is an embarrassment to the city. If this is what is supposed to represent San Francisco cafe society, I hang my head in shame. I've had mediocre coffee here before. Today, I was ready to order an iced coffee because of the heat, but decided to go for gelato instead. I ordered two flavors like any good Italian order would be and I got a dixie cup with my 2 scoops in it. I'm not exaggerating. It was a dixie cup with the Emporio Rulli logo and colors on it! It was such a small cup that they couldn't maneuver the standard side-by-side gelato service in it. What's worse, the gelato was only so-so and it cost me $3.50!  I was expecting at least a regular "small" cup if anything, but not a dixie cup! I would steer everyone to Naia in North Beach where, although the cups are also small, they are large enough to fit a good serving into it and they put more thought and effort into their flavors. Rulli only offers 5, maybe 6, flavors.... all of the American persuasion... vanilla, coffee, mint chip, vanilla. I can't remember the 5th.

I'm not expecting American-size scoops as big as my head, but give me SOMETHING for my money. Gelato is NOT more expensive to make and there really is no reason to charge more for it other than the "exotic" name of gelato. 

Locals/Tourists - buy your coffee here if you must, but buy food, pastries, and gelato elsewhere! I can recommend Naia for gelato in North Beach; crepes and chocolates at Crepe o Chocolat on off O'Farrel and Stockton (near Crate and Barrel), frozen yogurt at Fro Yo on Market and 3rd, and pastries at Boulangerie on Market. I think Caffe de la Presse would even be a good alternative.
author: Maria Y.

description: I know they must be busy at this cafe due to its location, but frankly it was horrible from start to finish. The paninis were pre-made and horrible, with wilted greens and just not good in general. How can you mess up a panini? The service was atrocious and you can't tell where to sit for service. The waiter actively avoided us for the first 10 minutes while we sat and waited for menus.
author: Lisa k.
